{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2014}} {{Use British English|date=April 2014}} {{Lead rewrite|date=May 2014}} {{Infobox Officeholder | honorific-prefix = | name = The Count de Salis | honorific-suffix = | image = File:John, 9th Count de Salis, southern England, July 2011.jpg | imagesize = | caption = Count de Salis, photographed in southern England, July 2011.<ref>He is wearing the De Salis summer tie he designed and had had [[Dege & Skinner|Dege]] manufacture).</ref> | order1 = | term_start1 = | term_end1 = | monarch1 = | primeminister1 = | predecessor1 = [[John Eugène, 8th Count de Salis-Soglio|John Eugène, 8th Count de Salis]] | successor1 = John-Maximilian Henry, 10th Count de Salis-Soglio | birth_date = {{birth date|1947|11|16|df=y}} | birth_place = London | death_date = {{death date and age|2014|03|14|1947|11|16|df=y}} | death_place = [[Mezzane di Sotto]], [[Veneto]], [[Italy]] | nationality = UK/SOM/Swiss/Italian | party = | alma_mater = [[Corpus Christi College, Cambridge]] | spouse = }} [[File:Detail of label of Conti de Salis-Soglio Amarone della Valpolicella, 2007.jpg|thumbnail|Close up on a bottle of Conti de Salis-Soglio Amarone della Valpolicella, 2007. The label features the Count's full heraldic achievement and one of the [[ogee]] arched topped windows of the facade of Verona's Palazzo Salis-Soglio.]] '''John Bernard Philip Humbert de Salis, 9th Count de Salis-[[Soglio, Switzerland|Soglio]]''',<ref>Genealogisches Handbuch des Adels, Gräfliche Häuser, Band XIX, 2009</ref> [[Territorial Decoration|TD]], ''John da Buri'', Graf v. Salis-Soglio, (London, 16 November 1947-Cà Buri, [[Mezzane di Sotto]], [[Veneto]], [[Italy]] 14 March 2014<ref>{{cite web|url=http://announcements.telegraph.co.uk/deaths/175153/john-bernard-philip-humbert-9th-count-de-salis |title=John Bernard Philip Humbert, 9th Count de Salis - Deaths Announcements |website=Announcements.telegraph.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2016-06-03}}</ref>); [[Holy Roman Empire|SRI]] [[Comes]], ''Illustris et Magnificus''; former [[International Committee of the Red Cross|ICRC]] delegate and envoy; Knight Grand Cross of Honour and Devotion (2000) of the [[Sovereign Military Order of Malta]] (knight, 1974), and Knight Grand Cross of the Order of Merit of the Order of Malta with Swords, first ambassador of the Order to Thailand 1986-98, Cambodia 1993-98, president of its Swiss Association (1995-2000) and of CIOMAL (Comité International de l'Ordre de Malte), 2000–08; British soldier and lawyer; [[Valpolicella]] vigneron and hereditary [[Knight of the Golden Spur (HRE)|Knight of the Golden Spur]].<ref>Debrett's, ''People of Today'', 2014</ref>
[[File:Peter III Chiavenna arms 2009.jpg|thumb|Imperial (Holy Roman Empire) arms of the Counts de Salis, as seen on the base of a now dismembered statue put up in Chiavenna in honour of [[Peter, 3rd Count de Salis]], a popular 1770s Governor of the Valtelline. (Photo: Chiavenna, 2009).]] A [[Imperial Count|Count]] of the [[Holy Roman Empire]] (Reichsgraf), (created by letters patent dated Vienna, 12 March 1748 for Envoy Peter de Salis-[[Soglio, Switzerland|Soglio]] (1675-1749), of Chur and Chiavenna, and his son [[Jerome, 2nd Count de Salis|Jerome]] (Naturalized British in 1731), by [[Francis I, Holy Roman Emperor|Emperor Francis I]]), John de Salis was the only child of Lt. Colonel [[John Eugène, 8th Count de Salis-Soglio|John Eugène, 8th Count de Salis]] (1891-1949),<ref>Burke's Irish Family Records, ed. Hugh Montgomery-Massingberd, Burke's Peerage Ltd, London, 1976.</ref> Irish Guards, by his Roman wife Maria Camilla (1926-1953), daughter of General Umberto Presti di Camarda by Teresa (d.1993), daughter of Filippo Nereo Vignola,<ref>Filippo Nereo Vignola was an amateur painter and dialect poet, as well as Podesta of Verona and Superintendent of the Museum of [[Castelvecchio (Verona)|Castelvecchio]] in Verona and Vicenza</ref> of Mezzane and Verona.
The grandson of the British diplomat, Irish landowner and Catholic re-convert Sir [[John Francis Charles, 7th Count de Salis-Soglio]], his earliest years were spent at 10 Priory Walk, Kensington, and 26 Roedean Crescent, Roehampton Gate, SW15. His father died when he was under two and his mother when he was five, his step-father when he was 10 and one of his two paternal uncles when he was four. His paternal grandparents had also died, in 1902 and 1939, so he was subsequently brought-up, inter-alia, by Franco-Belgian cousins in France (the widow and family of the 3rd [[Duc de Magenta]] at [[Château de Sully|Sully]], in particular), his remaining paternal uncle in Wiltshire, and his Veronese maternal grandmother, Teresa Vignola Presti.
He was educated at [[Downside School|Downside]], read law at [[Corpus Christi College, Cambridge]] (LLB (1972) and LLM), and was called to the Bar, [[Grays Inn]] (1970). Later he was a tenant and then door-tenant, at 1 Brick Court, Middle Temple, EC4, and from 1972 lived at 12 First Street, SW3 and then from 1975 in two houses knocked together at 28 Upper Cheyne Row, Chelsea, SW3. Whilst in London he was also a member of the board of management of the [[Hospital of St John and St Elizabeth]].
Alongside learning and practicing the law he served in the [[Officer Training Corps#Cambridge University|Cambridge University Officer Training Corps]] (CUOTC), the [[Honourable Artillery Company|HAC]] (within the [[Territorial and Army Volunteer Reserve]]), then in 1972, after meeting its then Colonel, [[Gilbert Monckton, 2nd Viscount Monckton of Brenchley|Viscount Monckton]], one of whose sisters-in-law happened to be married to one of John's first cousins, transferred to the [[9th/12th Royal Lancers]] (Prince of Wales's).<ref>London Gazette: Count John Bernard Philip Humbert DE SALIS (494322), 9/12 L. to be 2nd Lt. (on probation), 8 June 1972. [published 2 January 1973]</ref> He was with them in Northern Ireland<ref>London Gazette: Short Serv. Voluntary Commn. Lt. The Count John Bernard Philip Humbert DE SALIS (494322) 9/12L. from T.A.V.R., Group A to be Lt., 17 October 1977.</ref> and retired a (Brevet) Major<ref>London Gazette: Capt. (Bt. Maj.) The Count J. B. P. H. DE SALIS, T.D. (494322), 9/12 L. retires 22 December 1988.</ref> in 1988, having circa 1984 been awarded the Territorial Decoration.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.debretts.com/people-of-today/profile/11014/John-Bernard-Philip-Humbert-de-Salis-de-SALIS |archive-url=https://archive.is/20140404000648/http://www.debretts.com/people-of-today/profile/11014/John-Bernard-Philip-Humbert-de-Salis-de-SALIS |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2014-04-04 |title=People of Today Index, People of Today, People of Influence |website=Debretts.com |date= |accessdate=2016-06-03 }}</ref>
The combination of law of war, humanitarian instincts, soldiering and some family precedent (his father had been the Knight of Justice of the [[Order of St. John of Jerusalem]] delegate for the revision of the [[Geneva Convention]] in July 1929) lead De Salis to become the delegate of [[International Committee of the Red Cross]] Missions in the Middle East (Beirut, 1982<ref>'The War of Numbers' by Judith Tucker, ''MERIP Reports'', No. 108/109, The Lebanon War (September - October, 1982), pp. 47-50. Quoting John de Salis in the [[Washington Post]] of 4 August 1982.</ref>) and Africa (Rhodesia), and head of delegation in Iraq (1980–81) and Thailand (1981-84, Cambodian refugees), and their special envoy in Lebanon (1982). In July 1983 de Salis wrote: "It is a heartbreaking fact that ICRC being essentially concerned with the victims of armed conflicts, is more directly concerned operationally with the ''relief'' of suffering rather than its ''abolition''."<ref>Extract from a letter to the editor of [[The Times]], published 20 July 1983, in reply to an article by [[William Shawcross]]</ref>
On leaving England and moving to Switzerland he became a special officer in the Swiss Army's [[Panzergrenadiers]], and set about a new career as a financier: as partner of Gautier Salis et Cie Geneva (1989–96), vice-chairman of Bank Lips Zurich (1996–98), managing director of European Capital Partners (Switzerland) SA (1999-), and as director of Amadeus SA Geneva (2000-).<ref>Debrett's, ''People of Today'', 2014</ref> [[File:The Anatomy of Melancholy by Robert Burton frontispiece 1638 edition.jpg|thumb|100px|De Salis listed melancholia as his sole recreation.]] In the meantime he had taken over his grandmother's 160 acre farm in the Valle di Buri, Mezzane di Sotto, and developed it from dairy to vineyard.<ref>In 1995 he inherited the fourteenth century Nichesola house (Palazzo Somaglia-Stoppazzola/Palazzo Salis-Soglio) in Verona's Via Santa Felicita from his godfather Scipio, Conti Somaglia di Stoppazzola.</ref> By 2010 Conti de Salis-Soglio Wines Verona had taken shape, partly inspired by his courageous and visionary [[Valtelline]] cousin Conte Cesare Sertoli Salis of [[Tirano]] and Milan (1952-2005) and his ''Canua Sforzato'', akin to Valpolicella's [[Amarone]]. John's eighteenth century ancestors, [[Peter, 3rd Count de Salis|3rd Count Peter]] in particular, had also been growers of [[hemp]] and vines in eighteenth century Valtelline.<ref>Fane de Salis MSS</ref><ref>By 2014 his precarious and rather over ambitious operation comprised 8 acres of olives, 12 acres of vines for his own production of [[Amarone]] ([[Corvina]], Corvinino, [[Rondinella]] and [[Molinara (grape)|Molinara]], [[Croatina]], Oseleta, [[Raboso (grape)|Raboso]], Veronese and Dindarella grapes) and [[Pinot Noir|Pinot Nero]] for his neo-Burgundian ''Monte Rugoli'', with 80 acres for a while with the local agence Tenuta S. Antonio.</ref>
In addition to the above Count de Salis was a member of the British Association of the [[Sovereign Military Order of Malta]]; had the Gold Medal with Swords (Beirut) 1982; was a Knight of Justice of the [[Sacred Military Constantinian Order of Saint George]]; a Knight Grand Cross of the [[Order of the White Elephant]] (Thailand); and an hereditary [[Knight of the Golden Spur (HRE)|Knight of the Golden Spur (Eques Auratus)]] (1571).<ref>For [[Grisons]] envoy Giovanni Battista de Salis, the elder (1521-1597), of the Casa Alta, Soglio, invested by [[Pope Pius V]], 11 April 1571, perpetuating an earlier investiture of 1568.</ref>
[[File:Photo of title page of Poesie Brevi di C.V.Catullo tradotte in versi Veronesi da Filippo Nereo Vignola, Mondadori, Verona, 1925.jpg|thumbnail|''Poesie Brevi di C.V.Catullo'', a book of translations of [[Catullus]] by John de Salis' great-grandfather, Filippo Nereo Vignola, done at Cà da Buri, Mezzane.]]
He was next male representative of Charles, second and last [[Charles Fane, 2nd Viscount Fane|Viscount Fane]] and Baron of Loughuyre (aka [[Lough Gur]]), and of Vice-Admiral [[Francis William Drake]], of [[Hillingdon]], sometime governor of Newfoundland (1752-4), younger brother of the last Drake baronet of Buckland Abbey, and thus heir-general of Admiral Sir [[Francis Drake]] himself. His only listed recreation was ''melancholia''.<ref>Debrett's, ''People of Today'', 2014</ref>
==Clubs== He was a member of the [[Cavalry and Guards Club|Cavalry and Guards']], [[Beefsteak Club|Beefsteak]], Cercle de la Terasse (Geneva), Royal Bangkok Sports, and [[Chelsea Arts Club|Chelsea Arts]].<ref>Debrett's, ''People of Today'', 2014</ref>
==Family== He was firstly married to Samaritana Contessina di Serego [[Scaliger|della Scala]] (born 1950 in [[Verona]], [[Italy]]), daughter of Dr. Cortesia Conte di Serego, on 20 January 1973. Months later their marriage was [[Annulment|annulled]] and then [[Dissolution (law)|dissolved]] in 1985. They had no children.
He then married ([[Ormont-Dessus|Vers l’Eglise]], Vaud 1986) Marie-Claude (born in 1956 in [[Geneva]], [[Switzerland]]), third daughter of [[Swiss Army]] Colonel René-Henri Wüst and Marie-Thérèse Bussard. The couple had three children: *John-Maximilian Henry Fane de Salis, 10th Count de Salis-Soglio (b. 1986) *Lara Anastasia Fane de Salis (b. 1995) *Camille Charlotte Fane de Salis (b. 1995)
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
==Other sources== * {{cite news|title=Obituary: John de Salis|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/obituaries/10752920/John-de-Salis-obituary.html|work=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|date=9 April 2014}} * ''Burke's Peerage'', Foreign Noblemen / Foreign Titles sections: 1851, 1936, 1956, etc.; * ''[[Debrett's Peerage]]'', Foreign Titles section, 1920, 1925, etc.; * ''Der Grafliche Hauser'', Band XI [volume 11], [[:de:Genealogisches Handbuch des Adels|''Genealogisches Handbuch Des Adels'']], C. A. Starke Verlag, Limburg an der Lahn, 1983 (pps 331-356); * ''[[Burke's Peerage|Burke's]] Irish Family Records'', ed. [[Hugh Massingberd|Hugh Montgomery-Massingberd]], Burke's Peerage Ltd, London, 1976;
{{s-start}} {{s-reg|ir}} {{succession box | title=[[Count de Salis-Soglio]] | before=[[John Eugène, 8th Count de Salis-Soglio]] | after= John-Maximilian, 10th Count de Salis | years=1949–2014}} {{s-end}} {{Authority control}}

{{refimprove|date=August 2018}} {{orphan|date=July 2011}} {{Infobox musical artist |name = Jorge and Lorena Gamboa |image =<!--NOTE TO EDITORS: Do not introduce any fair use images in the infobox. Any fair use photos (i.e. promotional photos) are copyright violations and will be deleted. Also see http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Fair_use_criteria --> |caption = |background = group_or_band |birth_name = Jorge & Lorena Gamboa |alias = Jorge & Lorena |Married = 1988 |origin = |instrument = |genre = [[Contemporary Christian music|CCM]], [[Christian pop|balad]] |occupation = |years_active = 1988 - present |label = [[FICMI RECORS]] |associated_acts = |website = http://www.jorgeylorena.com/ |current_members = |past_members = }}
'''Jorge Gamboa''' and '''Lorena Gamboa''' are a [[Spain|Spanish]] couple known for their [[singing]] appearances on [[television]] programming on different channels: as DayStar, Family Christian Network, Familia TV Network and [[TBN Enlace]]. They currently travel the world as [[Christian]] [[Evangelism|evangelists]]. And are pastoring a church in Houston Texas.
==Overview== ===History=== The couple first met at the First Christian Music Contest, ''Canto de Libertad'', in [[Costa Rica]] in 1987. At the time, Lorena was a singer in a band called ''Encuentro'' and a [[special education]] teacher. She was also a student in ''Cristo al Mundo'' (Christ for the World) and an active member in the ''Movimiento Cristiano Juventud Neuva'' (New Youth Christian Movement). Jorge was a [[Solo (music)|soloist]], [[musician]], professional [[soccer]] player. They were married on September 17, 1988.<ref>Gamboa, Jorge y Lorena: ''Vale la Pena'', page 10. goodcatchpublishing Press, 2009.</ref>
===Career=== The Gamboas have recorded productions with widely varying styles and subjects. They became known as singers and teachers through the television program ''de pareja a pareja'', as well as through [[TBN Enlace]], at time called ''La Voz de la Cuadra'' (The Voice Around the Block). Today they are the founders of [[Familia TV Network]], based in Houston Texas.
===Evangelism=== In 1996 they joined Good News in Bad News Places Ministries and in 1998 they began their own full-time ministry as overseas [[Evangelism|evangelists]] preaching the [[Gospel of Jesus Christ]], imparting family seminars and have been in more than 60 countries around the world since they started. As an extension of their ministry they also belong to the Vida International Bible Institute and work as the [[Hispanic]] coordinators.
===Current musical performance=== The Gamboas participate in local TV programs such as: "de pareja a pareja" at Channel 21.2 FAMILIA TV, Bendicion TV 43.4, Familia TV 27.4, Celebration at Daystar and Diles at International Spanish TBN in [[Houston, Texas|Houston]], [[Texas]].
==Discography== ===Studio albums===
*1996: ''Nosotros'' *1999: ''Confio en Ti Senor" *2000: ''Te Exaltare'' *2005: ''Meditacion y Adoracion'' *2006: ''En Tu Presencia'' *2006: ''Del Corazon de un Adorador'' *2007: ''Serie Instrumentales'' *2008: ''Instrumental flauta, piano y sax'' *2009: ''Borron y cuenta Nueva''
==Books==
*''Marriage According to God'' *''Practical Evangelism'' *''Religions and Cults'' *''By the Power of His Presence'' *''Discipline, Correction and Punishment'' *''Free from Bondage'' *''Free to Worship Him'' *''Deliverance'' *''Courtship and Dating'' *''Vale la Pena'' *''Por el Poder de Su Presencia'' *''Como ser un Jose de este siglo'' *''El Matrimonio segun Dios'' *''Ciclos, etapas y estaciones del matrimonio'' *"Disciplina, Correccion y Castigo" *"Como Cultivar su relacion Matrimonial" *"Sexo e Intimidad en el Matrimonio" *"Mujeres, eso no fue lo que dijo Pablo"
==References== <references/>
==External links== *[http://www.jorgeylorena.com/ Official website] *[http://www.ficmi.org/ Jorge y Lorena Ministry Site] *[http://www.chiraisland.net/ Jorge y Lorena Missionary Training Center] *[http://www.myspace.com/jorgelorena Jorge y Lorena on myspace] *[http://www.tangle.com/jorgeylorena Jorge y Lorena on tangle.com]

revision.text:
{{Infobox NFL biography |name=Kyle Turley |image=Kyle Turley playing guitar and singing with a black shirt and black hat.jpg |image_size= |alt= |caption=Turley in 2010 |position=[[Offensive tackle]] |number=68, 74 |birth_date={{Birth date and age|1975|9|24|mf=y}} |birth_place=[[Provo, Utah]] |height_ft=6 |height_in=5 |weight_lbs=309 |high_school=[[Valley View High School (Moreno Valley, California)|Valley View (Moreno Valley, CA)]] |college=[[San Diego State Aztecs football|San Diego State]] |draftyear=1998 |draftround=1 |draftpick=7 |pastteams= * [[New Orleans Saints]] ({{NFL Year|1998}}–{{NFL Year|2002}}) * [[St. Louis Rams]] ({{NFL Year|2003}}–{{NFL Year|2004}}) * [[Kansas City Chiefs]] ({{NFL Year|2006}}–{{NFL Year|2007}}) |highlights= * 2× First-team [[All-Pro]] ([[2000 All-Pro Team|2000]], [[2003 All-Pro Team|2003]]) * Consensus [[College Football All-America Team|All-American]] ([[1997 College Football All-America Team|1997]]) |statlabel1=Games played |statvalue1=109 |statlabel2=Games started |statvalue2=107 |statlabel3=Fumbles recovered |statvalue3=8 |nflnew=kyleturley/2503417 |pfr=TurlKy20 }}
'''Kyle John Turley''' (born September 24, 1975) is a former [[American football]] [[offensive lineman]] who played eight seasons in the [[National Football League]] (NFL). Selected 7th overall in the [[1998 NFL draft]], Turley played five seasons for the [[New Orleans Saints]] and a year with the [[St. Louis Rams]] before a serious back injury sidelined him for the 2004 and 2005 seasons. He returned to football in 2006 as a member of the [[Kansas City Chiefs]], where he spent the last two years of his career before announcing his retirement in December 2007. Turley's high level of play earned him [[All-Pro]] honors for the 2000 season and a [[Pro Bowl]] invite following the 2001 season. His career is best remembered by many for a 2001 incident in which he ripped off an opposing player's helmet and tossed it downfield, playing a key factor in his team losing the game but also earning the respect of many Saints fans for his defense of the quarterback. Turley played college football at [[San Diego State Aztecs football|San Diego State]].
Following his retirement from football, Turley set out on a music career that included the release of several albums and the launch of his own record label. Playing his "power country" style of music, Turley opened for a number of well-known musical acts, including in 2010 when he went on tour with [[Hank Williams III]]. Turley has also been outspoken and involved in a number of player health issues post-retirement, particularly in regards to the neurological problems resulting from his football career ([[Early-onset Alzheimer's disease|early onset Alzheimer's]], [[Chronic traumatic encephalopathy|CTE symptomatic]], [[seizures]], [[vertigo]]) and his use of [[Cannabis (drug)|cannabis]] as treatment. Turley is a board member and active supporter of the Gridiron Greats Assistance Fund, an organization providing medical care and other forms of assistance to retired NFL players in dire need.
==Early years== Turley was born in [[Provo, Utah]].<ref name="afl" /> He lived in [[Utah]] as well as the state of [[Washington (state)|Washington]] before moving to southern [[California]] at the age of 10.<ref name="247 passion" /> Growing up Turley enjoyed [[surfing]] and [[skateboarding]], and took an interest in music.<ref name="afl" /><ref name="247 passion" />
Turley attended [[Valley View High School (Moreno Valley, California)|Valley View High School]] in [[Moreno Valley, California]].<ref name="chiefs bio" /> He played defensive end during his only season of football as a senior in 1992,<ref name="afl">{{cite news|last1=Hewitt|first1=Hunter|title=Throwback Thursday: Kyle Turley|url=https://aztecsforlife.com/2012/08/30/throwback-thursday-kyle-turley/|accessdate=August 14, 2016|work=Aztecs for Life: SDSU Football Blog|date=August 30, 2012}}</ref> earning first-team all-league honors<ref name="chiefs bio" /> and attracting athletic scholarship offers from several universities seeking to recruit him.<ref name="afl" /> Turley also played baseball<ref name="cs interview" /> and was recognized with all-state honors as a wrestler.<ref name="chiefs bio" />
==College career== Turley played college football at [[San Diego State University]], [[Redshirt (college sports)|redshirting]] his first year in 1993.<ref name="afl" /> During his time on the scout team he practiced on both the offensive and defensive line, and was given the choice afterwards of where he wanted to play.<ref name="afl" /> Turley chose offensive line as it allowed him the opportunity to work with O-line coach [[Ed White (American football)|Ed White]],<ref>{{cite news|last1=Silver|first1=Michael|title=Kyle Turley -- Chiefs OT discusses his weight, steroids, rock and roll|url=http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/2006/writers/michael_silver/09/13/turley/index.html|work=Sports Illustrated|date=September 13, 2006|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071229150431/http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/2006/writers/michael_silver/09/13/turley/index.html|archive-date=December 29, 2007}}</ref> a 17-year veteran of the NFL who played in four [[Super Bowl]]s.<ref name="247 passion" /> Turley's most notable achievements came his final season in 1997, earning first-team [[All-American]] honors and being named a semifinalist for the [[Lombardi Award]] and [[Outland Trophy]].<ref>{{cite news|title=One for the ages|url=http://www.thedailyaztec.com/19455/daily-aztec-stories/one-for-the-ages/|accessdate=October 1, 2016|work=The Daily Aztec|date=December 15, 1997}}</ref> He was also twice named All-[[Western Athletic Conference]] first team during his time at SDSU.<ref name="aztecs bio">{{cite web|title=Kyle Turley Bio|url=http://www.goaztecs.com/sports/m-footbl/mtt/turley_kyle00.html|website=goaztecs.com|accessdate=August 14, 2016}}</ref> Turley was inducted into the Aztec Hall of Fame in 2011.<ref name="aztecs bio" />
==Professional career==
===New Orleans Saints=== Turley was selected 7th overall by the [[New Orleans Saints]] in the [[1998 NFL draft]]. Initially not projected as a high first round pick, Turley's draft stock rose dramatically after turning in a stellar 4.93 seconds for the [[40-yard dash]] at the [[NFL combine]].<ref name="espn combine">{{cite news|last1=Drehs|first1=Wayne|title=Wealth is measured in tenths of a second|url=http://a.espncdn.com/nfl/s/2002/0221/1338037.html|accessdate=August 10, 2016|work=ESPN|date=February 21, 2002}}</ref> Turley's performance caught the eye of then-Saints coach [[Mike Ditka]], and the team subsequently made him the first offensive linemen selected in the 1998 draft.<ref name="espn combine" /> He signed a six-year contract on July 24, 1998.<ref name="chiefs bio">{{cite web|title=KYLE TURLEY #74|url=http://www.kcchiefs.com/player/kyle_turley/|website=kcchiefs.com|accessdate=August 5, 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080210030650/http://www.kcchiefs.com/player/kyle_turley/|archive-date=February 10, 2008}}</ref>
Turley played a total of five seasons for the Saints, making an immediate impact by starting 15 games his rookie season and earning all-rookie honors from ''[[Pro Football Weekly]]'', ''Football News'', and ''[[Football Digest]]''.<ref name="chiefs bio" /> A durable presence on the Saints offensive line, Turley missed only one game due to ankle injury during his five years in New Orleans.<ref>{{cite web|title=Kyle Turley|url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/players/T/TurlKy20.htm|website=Pro Football Reference|accessdate=September 28, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Haugh|first1=David|title=Turley joins fray for NFL retirees|url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2007-11-28/sports/0711280093_1_nfl-retirees-kyle-turley-saints-coach|accessdate=September 28, 2016|work=Chicago Tribune|date=November 28, 2007}}</ref> Turley would prove to be a versatile player as well, starting mostly at left guard his rookie season, then moving to right tackle the next three seasons, and over to left tackle in 2002.<ref name="chiefs bio" /> His strong play earned him first team [[All-Pro]] honors following the 2000 season<ref name="chiefs bio" /> and an invitation to the [[Pro Bowl]] as a substitute following the 2001 season.<ref name="latimes dirty" /> He would turn down the Pro Bowl invite to serve as grand marshall of the [[Krewe of Endymion|Endymion Parade]] during [[New Orleans Mardi Gras|Mardi Gras]], however.<ref>{{cite news|title=Ex-ICC standout turns down Pro Bowl offer|url=http://www.djournal.com/news/ex-icc-standout-turns-down-pro-bowl-offer/article_20371ba6-294d-57b3-a779-012fc31c4f0b.html|accessdate=June 7, 2017|work=djournal.com|agency=Associated Press|date=February 6, 2002}}</ref>
During his time in New Orleans, Turley became a fan favorite for his spirited style of play and colorful personality.<ref name="latimes dirty" /> His popularity especially took off after the helmet tossing incident of 2001,<ref>{{cite news|last1=Wilde|first1=Jason|title=Supportive Packers linemen say Turley far from Sainthood|url=http://journaltimes.com/news/state-and-regional/supportive-packers-linemen-say-turley-far-from-sainthood/article_0bfdc4e2-29c6-5501-be82-7c2eaa026b38.html|accessdate=August 10, 2016|work=The Journal Times|date=September 14, 2002}}</ref> with many Saints fans lining up to buy his jersey afterwards.<ref name="latimes dirty" /><ref name="nola fight" /> Turley's antics were less well-received among team management however, particularly leading up to his March 2003 trade when Turley engaged in a public dispute with general manager [[Mickey Loomis]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Duncan |first1=Jeff |title=Turley's talk may be hurting his trade value |url=http://www.nola.com/sports/t-p/index.ssf?/base/sports-1/1047797712100510.xml |work=The Times-Picayune |date=March 16, 2003 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20030402020654/http://www.nola.com/sports/t-p/index.ssf?%2Fbase%2Fsports-1%2F1047797712100510.xml |archive-date=April 2, 2003 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Silver|first1=Michael|title=Bitter Turley comes clean on why he's no Saint|url=http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/inside_game/michael_silver/news/2003/06/05/open_mike/|work=Sports Illustrated|date=June 5, 2003|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20030713205412/http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/inside_game/michael_silver/news/2003/06/05/open_mike/|archive-date=July 13, 2003}}</ref> Amongst players in the league, Turley came to be known by some as a dirty player due to his frequent use of [[cut block]]s and ambushing of unsuspecting defenders.<ref name="latimes dirty">{{cite news|last1=Farmer|first1=Sam|title=He's No Saint|url=http://articles.latimes.com/print/2002/sep/05/sports/sp-turley5|accessdate=August 10, 2016|work=Los Angeles Times|date=September 5, 2002}}</ref><ref name="si dirty" /> Turley defended his use of the cut block, noting that it is a legal maneuver and that he is simply doing his job within the rules of the game.<ref name="si dirty">{{cite news|last1=Elliot|first1=Josh|title=Jekyll & Hyde|url=https://www.si.com/vault/1969/12/31/8118108/jekyll--hyde-he-may-be-affable-off-the-field-but-on-it-saints-allpro-tackle-kyle-turley-hasnt-won-any-friends-with-his-style-of-play|accessdate=August 10, 2016|work=Sports Illustrated|date=July 2, 2001}}</ref>
Turley's football career is best remembered by many for an on-field altercation that occurred in a game against the [[New York Jets]] on November 4, 2001. Trailing 16–9 in the final minute of the game, the Saints were driving deep into opposition territory with the ball at the 6-yard line on second-and-3.<ref name="usatoday fight">{{cite news|title=Turley defends actions against Jets|url=http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/sports/nfl/saints/2001-11-05-turley.htm|accessdate=August 5, 2016|work=USA Today|agency=Associated Press|date=November 5, 2001}}</ref> After quarterback [[Aaron Brooks (American football)|Aaron Brooks]] was tackled on a scramble to the 5-yard line, Jets safety [[Damien Robinson]] grabbed him by the facemask and proceeded to bend his body backwards while forcefully twisting his head to the side.<ref name="nola fight">{{cite news|last1=Hogan|first1=Nakia|title=Ex-New Orleans Saints Kyle Turley recalls tirade for the ages|url=http://www.nola.com/saints/index.ssf/2011/11/ex-new_orleans_saints_kyle_tur.html|accessdate=August 5, 2016|work=The Times-Picayune|date=November 4, 2011}}</ref> Turley stepped in and separated the two, then picked up Robinson by the facemask and threw him to the ground as referees and players from both teams tried to break up the scrum.<ref name="nola fight" /> Turley emerged from the pile with Robinson's helmet in hand and proceeded to fling it across the field before making an obscene gesture.<ref name="usatoday fight" /> Robinson and Turley received offsetting personal fouls for the initial incident, but Turley was assessed an additional personal foul and ejected from the game for the helmet toss and obscene gesture.<ref name="usatoday fight" /> The penalty set the Saints back 15 yards and they ended up losing the game after failing to score on the drive. Saints head coach [[Jim Haslett]] said he initially considered cutting Turley before seeing a clearer view of the incident on film and discussing it with quarterback [[Aaron Brooks (American football)|Aaron Brooks]], who thought his neck had been broken at the time.<ref name="usatoday fight" /> Turley was subsequently fined $25,000 by the Saints organization and requested to attend counseling for [[anger management|management of anger issues]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Pasquarelli|first1=Len|title=Robinson fined $20,000 by league|url=http://a.espncdn.com/nfl/news/2001/1107/1274769.html|accessdate=August 10, 2016|work=ESPN|date=November 7, 2001}}</ref> Many Saints fans applauded Turley's actions on the other hand, setting up a "Kyle Turley Defense Fund" to assist in payment of the fine<ref>{{cite news|last1=Patrick|first1=Dan|title=Outtakes with Kyle Turley|url=http://www.espn.com/talent/danpatrick/s/2002/0919/1433808.html|accessdate=August 11, 2016|work=ESPN|date=October 1, 2002}}</ref> and putting up "Turley for mayor" signs around the city.<ref name="cs interview" /> The incident occurred during a nationally televised game and received a significant amount of media attention afterwards, putting Turley's name in the national spotlight for the first time.<ref name="nola fight" />
===St. Louis Rams=== Turley was traded to the [[St. Louis Rams]] on March 21, 2003, in exchange for a 2nd round pick in the 2004 draft.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Duncan |first1=Jeff |title=Turley says he's excited to join Rams |url=http://www.nola.com/saints/t-p/index.ssf?/base/sports-0/1048751785281280.xml |work=The Times-Picayune |date=March 27, 2003 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20030419062359/http://www.nola.com/saints/t-p/index.ssf?%2Fbase%2Fsports-0%2F1048751785281280.xml |archive-date=April 19, 2003 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> He was immediately signed to a 5-year, $26.5 million extension (in addition to the one year remaining on his contract),<ref>{{cite news|title=Rams bolster line with trade for Saints' Turley|url=http://bengals.enquirer.com/2003/03/23/wwwbenznote23.html|accessdate=August 6, 2016|work=Cincinnati Enquirer|date=March 23, 2003}}</ref> making Turley the fourth-highest paid offensive lineman in the league.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Pasquarelli|first1=Len|title=Rams give up second-round pick for Turley|url=http://a.espncdn.com/nfl/columns/pasquarelli_len/1527506.html|accessdate=August 10, 2016|work=ESPN|date=March 24, 2003}}</ref> With future hall-of-famer [[Orlando Pace]] already entrenched at the starting left tackle position, Turley moved to the right side and started all 16 regular games plus the single playoff game of the Rams 2003 season.<ref name="chiefs bio" /> During week 7, Turley suffered a severe [[concussion]] after taking a knee to the back of the head,<ref name="yahoo seizure" /> but he was cleared for practice by mid-week and started the next game<ref name="ny seizure" /> (as Turley would later attest in a January 2010 congressional hearing on the NFL's handling of concussions).<ref name="Turley testimony" /> In December 2003, Turley was featured on the cover of ''[[Sports Illustrated]]''.<ref>{{cite web|title=This Issue's Contents – December 08, 2003|url=https://www.si.com/vault/issue/703299/1/1|website=Sports Illustrated|accessdate=August 8, 2016}}</ref>
Turley underwent surgery to repair a [[Spinal disc herniation|herniated disc]] in March 2004.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Fallstrom|first1=R.B.|title=Turley departs camp with more back problems|url=http://www.semissourian.com/story/143031.html|accessdate=September 27, 2016|work=Southeast Missourian|agency=Associated Press|date=August 2, 2004}}</ref> He re-aggravated the injury during training camp and was placed on [[injured reserve]] on August 28, ending his season.<ref name="espn plagued">{{cite news|last1=Pasquarelli|first1=Len|title=Offensive lineman plagued by back problems|url=http://www.espn.com/nfl/columns/story?id=1874470&columnist=pasquarelli_len|accessdate=August 7, 2016|work=ESPN|date=September 4, 2004}}</ref> Turley ruled out a second surgery on his back and opted for a long rehabilitation instead,<ref>{{cite news|last1=Pasquarelli|first1=Len|title=Turley still rejects surgery, has lost 70 pounds|url=http://www.espn.com/nfl/columns/story?id=1947031&columnist=pasquarelli_len|accessdate=September 27, 2016|work=ESPN|date=December 15, 2004}}</ref> during which his weight dropped to 235 pounds from a normal playing weight of 310.<ref name="si defense" /> In December, he was involved in a heated exchange regarding the matter with head coach [[Mike Martz]], after which Martz filed a complaint with NFL security.<ref name="espn argument">{{cite news|title=Turley says he did not threaten Martz|url=http://www.espn.com/nfl/news/story?id=1954691|accessdate=August 7, 2016|work=ESPN|agency=Associated Press|date=December 29, 2004}}</ref> No disciplinary action was taken as a result,<ref>{{cite news|title=Rams say matter is closed|url=http://www.espn.com/nfl/news/story?id=1957521|accessdate=August 7, 2016|work=ESPN|date=January 2, 2005}}</ref> but Turley admitted that hard feelings lingered.<ref name="sdut defense" /> Turley also harbored feelings of resentment leading up to the incident, believing that the organization acted recklessly and carelessly in pushing him to return from back surgery too soon and advising him to play through initial onset of the injury during the 2003 season.<ref name="cs interview">{{cite news|last1=McCollough|first1=Brady|title=Natural born protector Turley now protecting Trent Green's backside|url=http://www.coveringsports.com/turley.htm|accessdate=August 7, 2016|work=Kansas City Star|date=August 27, 2006}}</ref><ref name="espn argument" /> During his continued rehabilitation in 2005, Turley suggested he may switch to the defensive end position to lessen the load on his back.<ref name="si defense">{{cite news|last1=Silver|first1=Michael|title=Getting defensive -- Turley wants to bring his intensity to DE position|url=http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/2005/writers/michael_silver/06/10/silver.turley/index.html|work=Sports Illustrated|date=June 10, 2005|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20050829125059/http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/2005/writers/michael_silver/06/10/silver.turley/index.html|archive-date=August 29, 2005}}</ref><ref name="sdut defense">{{cite news|last1=Schrotenboer|first1=Brent|title=Turley eyes changing sides|url=http://legacy.sandiegouniontribune.com/uniontrib/20050402/news_1s2turley.html|accessdate=August 7, 2016|work=San Diego Union-Tribune|date=April 2, 2005}}</ref> He was released by the Rams on June 6, 2005, however, after failing a physical.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Pasquarelli|first1=Len|title=Turley still rehabbing from back injury|url=http://www.espn.com/nfl/columns/story?id=2078852&columnist=pasquarelli_len|accessdate=August 7, 2005|work=ESPN|date=June 8, 2005}}</ref> He ended up spending the entire 2004 and 2005 seasons out of football, continuing his recovery and training for a return in 2006.<ref name="cs interview" />
===Kansas City Chiefs=== After a mini-camp tryout at tight end for the [[Miami Dolphins]],<ref>{{cite news|last1=Pasquarelli|first1=Len|title=Turley tries to return from back problems|url=http://www.espn.com/nfl/news/story?id=2434536|accessdate=August 8, 2016|work=ESPN|date=May 5, 2006}}</ref> Turley signed a two-year contract with the [[Kansas City Chiefs]] on June 13, 2006, where he would compete for a starting job at the right tackle position.<ref>{{cite news|title=Chiefs sign offensive tackle Kyle Turley|url=http://www.kansascity.com/mld/kansascity/sports/football/nfl/kansas_city_chiefs/14809805.htm|accessdate=August 8, 2016|work=Kansas City Star|agency=Associated Press|date=June 13, 2006|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060701095140/http://www.kansascity.com/mld/kansascity/sports/football/nfl/kansas_city_chiefs/14809805.htm|archive-date=July 1, 2006}}</ref> He started the first two games of the season, but recurring back problems and a shoulder injury late in the season ended up limiting him to 7 starts in 7 games played.<ref name="chiefs bio" /> He was also overpowered at times on the field due to playing below his normal weight from before his 2004 back surgery.<ref name="espn chiefs">{{cite news|last1=Pasquarelli|first1=Len|title=Chiefs sign Turley to contract ahead of training camp|url=http://www.espn.com/nfl/news/story?id=2949349|accessdate=August 8, 2016|work=ESPN|date=July 25, 2007}}</ref>
Turley was released by the Chiefs in March 2007, but re-signed to a new one-year contract on July 26, 2007.<ref name="espn chiefs" /> Having regained most of his normal playing weight in the offseason, Turley reported to training camp at 300 pounds.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Pompei|first1=Dan|title=Weight watcher, all right -- Turley perfects putting on pounds: Eat, sleep, lift|url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2007-09-14/sports/0709131223_1_weight-gain-weight-watcher-kyle-turley|accessdate=September 26, 2016|work=Chicago Tribune|date=September 14, 2007}}</ref> Turley's health would again be an issue during the season however, as he dealt with hamstring,<ref>{{cite web|title=2007 Week 5 Injury Report|url=http://www.jt-sw.com/football/pro/index.nsf/Documents/2007-ir-05|website=jt-sw.com|accessdate=August 8, 2016}}</ref> ankle,<ref>{{cite web|title=2007 Week 15 Injury Report|url=http://www.jt-sw.com/football/pro/index.nsf/Documents/2007-ir-15|website=jt-sw.com|accessdate=August 8, 2016}}</ref> and back problems.<ref>{{cite web|title=2007 Week 14 Injury Report|url=http://www.jt-sw.com/football/pro/index.nsf/Documents/2007-ir-14|website=jt-sw.com|accessdate=August 8, 2016}}</ref> He started 5 of 7 games played in and ended the season on injured reserve.<ref name="latimes retire" /> Turley announced his retirement from football on December 21, 2007.<ref name="latimes retire">{{cite news|last1=Johnson|first1=Greg|title=Amid activism, Turley will retire|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2007/dec/22/sports/sp-nflrep22|accessdate=August 8, 2016|work=Los Angeles Times|date=December 22, 2007}}</ref>
==Life after football==
===Music career===
====Early years==== Turley's passion for music began early in life, taking up the [[guitar]] at age 14.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Farrar|first1=Doug|title=Outside the Game: Kyle Turley hopes to get back to NFL stadiums — this time, with his band|url=https://sports.yahoo.com/blogs/shutdown-corner/outside-game-kyle-turley-hopes-back-nfl-stadiums-194433648--nfl.html|accessdate=September 8, 2016|work=Yahoo! Sports|date=October 9, 2012}}</ref> He listened to [[Punk rock|punk]], [[grunge]], and [[Heavy metal music|metal]] growing up as a teenager in southern California, and was also exposed heavily to [[country music]] from being around his father.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Mourning|first1=Zhan|title=Gridiron Experts Catches Up With Kyle Turley|url=http://gridironexperts.com/kyle-turley-interviewed|accessdate=September 8, 2016|work=Gridiron Experts|date=October 16, 2012}}</ref> During his football career Turley played in a number of bands in the offseason, including various [[cover band]]s<ref name="rnr interview">{{cite news|last1=Mosqueda|first1=Ruben|title=Interview with Kyle Turley|url=http://rockandrollazine.blogspot.com/2010/04/interview-with-kyle-turley.html|work=Rock & Rolla|date=April 9, 2010|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111027143933/http://rockandrollazine.blogspot.com/2010/04/interview-with-kyle-turley.html|archive-date=October 27, 2011}}</ref> and a [[death metal]] band named Perpetual Death Mode.<ref>{{cite news|title=PERPETUAL DEATH MODE: Former NFL Pro Bowl Offensive Lineman KYLE TURLEY Blasting Away|url=http://www.blabbermouth.net/news/perpetual-death-mode-former-nfl-pro-bowl-offensive-lineman-kyle-turley-blasting-away/|accessdate=September 11, 2016|work=blabbermouth.net|date=June 19, 2005}}</ref> He also [[Jam session|jammed]] with other NFL players,<ref name="247 passion">{{cite news|last1=Ryan|first1=Kevin|title=Turley: Passion beyond the gridiron|url=https://247sports.com/Article/Kyle-Turley-to-use-his-All-Pro-knowledge-to-evaluate-OL-for-247-70385|work=247Sports|date=April 7, 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120607012925/http://247sports.com/Article/Kyle-Turley-to-use-his-All-Pro-knowledge-to-evaluate-OL-for-247-70385|archive-date=June 7, 2012}}</ref> and learned to play [[Bass guitar|bass]] and [[Drum kit|drums]].<ref name="rnr interview" /> While living in New Orleans, Turley immersed himself heavily in the local music scene where he befriended a number of musicians, including [[Phil Anselmo]] from [[Pantera]].<ref name="csc interview">{{cite news|last1=Cariello|first1=Dave|title=CSC Interview: Kyle Turley|url=http://www.canalstreetchronicles.com/2010/8/26/1648938/csc-interview-kyle-turley|accessdate=September 8, 2016|work=canalstreetchronicles.com|date=August 26, 2010}}</ref><ref name="pmtm interview" /> Turley continued networking and honing his musical abilities in St. Louis, jamming with local musicians and performing at a number of charity events.<ref name="rft music">{{cite news|last1=Tucker|first1=John H.|title=Kyle Turley Back in St. Louis -- This Time as a Musician, Not a Football Player|url=http://www.riverfronttimes.com/musicblog/2010/12/17/kyle-turley-back-in-st-louis-this-time-as-a-musician-not-a-football-player?showFullText=true|accessdate=September 8, 2016|work=Riverfront Times|date=December 17, 2010}}</ref>
====The Kyle Turley Band==== A year after retiring from football, Turley moved to [[Nashville, Tennessee|Nashville]] where he set his sights on pursuing a music career.<ref name="afl" /> He formed The Kyle Turley Band and released his first album, a 4-track self-titled [[Extended play|EP]], in 2009.<ref>{{cite web|title=EP|url=https://itunes.apple.com/us/album/ep/id339921807|website=itunes.apple.com|accessdate=September 8, 2016}}</ref> His first full-length album, ''Anger Management'', was released in 2010 and included all songs from the earlier EP.<ref>{{cite web|title=Anger Management|url=https://itunes.apple.com/us/album/anger-management/id358850474|website=itunes.apple.com|accessdate=September 8, 2016}}</ref> The album sold over 10,000 copies<ref name="nola fight" /> and reached as high as No. 69 and 17 on the [[iTunes]] and [[AmazonMP3]] country charts respectively,<ref name="rft music" /> while also charting at No. 8 on [[Billboard charts|Billboard]]'s [[Top Heatseekers|Heatseekers]] South Central chart.<ref name="rft music" /> His next album, a 6-song EP titled ''Death, Drugs & the DoubleCross'',<ref>{{cite web|title=Death, Drugs & the DoubleCross - EP|url=https://itunes.apple.com/us/album/death-drugs-doublecross-ep/id466474398|website=itunes.apple.com|accessdate=September 8, 2016}}</ref> came out in 2011 and became the top selling album in New Orleans, as well as reaching #1 on Billboard's Heatseekers South Central chart<ref>{{cite news|title=Death, Drugs & the DoubleCross is #1 Album in New Orleans, LA|url=http://www.gridironrecords.com/death-drugs-the-doublecross-is-1-album-in-new-orleans-la/|accessdate=September 10, 2016|work=Gridiron Records|date=October 23, 2011|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160910212514/http://www.gridironrecords.com/death-drugs-the-doublecross-is-1-album-in-new-orleans-la/|archive-date=September 10, 2016|dead-url=usurped}}</ref> and #28 on the Heatseekers chart overall.<ref>{{cite news|title=#1 Album in South Central Region & #28 in US on Billboard Heatseekers Chart!|url=http://www.gridironrecords.com/1-album-in-south-central-region-28-in-us-on-billboard-heatseekers-chart/|accessdate=September 10, 2016|work=Gridiron Records|date=November 18, 2011|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160910212716/http://www.gridironrecords.com/1-album-in-south-central-region-28-in-us-on-billboard-heatseekers-chart/|archive-date=September 10, 2016|dead-url=usurped}}</ref> Turley's second full-length album ''Skull Shaker'' was released in 2013.<ref>{{cite web|title=Skull Shaker|url=https://itunes.apple.com/us/album/skull-shaker/id687554849|website=itunes.apple.com|accessdate=September 8, 2016}}</ref>
Turley sings and plays guitar for The Kyle Turley Band. He describes his style of music as "power country", drawing influences from old-school [[Country music|country]], [[Heavy metal music|heavy metal]], [[Southern rock]], and [[punk rock]].<ref name="rft music" /> Some of Turley's song lyrics make reference to his football career, including the tracks "Flyin' Helmets" and "Anger Management" which allude to Turley's helmet tossing incident.<ref name="csc interview" /> The song "My Soul Bleeds Black and Gold" is a tribute to the city of New Orleans and its football team,<ref name="wdd interview">{{cite news|last1=Null|first1=Keith|title=Interview With Former Saints First Round Pick OT Kyle Turley Turned "Power Country" Star|url=http://whodatdish.com/2010/08/27/interview-with-former-saints-first-round-pick-ot-kyle-turley-turned-power-country-star/|accessdate=September 12, 2016|work=Who Dat Dish|date=August 27, 2010}}</ref> which in the years since his 2003 departure Turley has expressed regret for leaving.<ref name="wdd interview" /><ref>{{cite news|last1=Rose|first1=Chris|title=Former New Orleans Saint's Kyle Turley now a music man|url=http://www.nola.com/rose/index.ssf/2009/10/the_60-second_interview_kyle_t.html|accessdate=September 9, 2016|work=The Times-Picayune|date=October 9, 2009}}</ref>
Turley has toured extensively with his band, including in spring 2010 when he hit the road with [[Hank Williams III]] across the western United States.<ref name="rn bio">{{cite web|title=Kyle Turley / Bio|url=https://www.reverbnation.com/kyleturley/bio|website=ReverbNation|accessdate=September 8, 2016}}</ref> Other acts that Turley has opened for include [[Lynyrd Skynyrd]], [[Eric Church]], [[Joe Nichols]], [[George Jones]], [[Jake Owen]], [[David Allan Coe]], [[Josh Thompson (singer)|Josh Thompson]], and [[Kansas (band)|Kansas]].<ref name="rn bio" />
====Delta Doom==== Delta Doom is a two-piece [[doom metal]] project that Turley formed in 2013 with bassist Rob Ogles from The Kyle Turley Band.<ref>{{cite web|title=DELTA DOOM / Bio|url=https://www.reverbnation.com/deltadoom/bio|website=ReverbNation|accessdate=September 9, 2016}}</ref> Ogles is the band's guitarist while Turley sings and plays drums.<ref name="pmtm interview">{{cite news|last1=Ward|first1=Mike|title=PMTM: The Kyle Turley Interview|url=https://passmethemike.com/2013/08/14/pmtm-the-kyle-turley-interview/|accessdate=September 8, 2016|work=Pass Me the Mike|date=August 14, 2013}}</ref> Their first album, a 4-track live EP titled ''Half Alive'', was released in December 2013.<ref>{{cite web|title=Demented Spotlight Featured Band|url=http://www.dementedmagazine2.com/|website=Demented Magazine|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140321033955/http://www.dementedmagazine2.com/|archive-date=March 21, 2014}}</ref> Delta Doom has toured as an opening act for the New Orleans [[sludge metal]] band [[Crowbar (American band)|Crowbar]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Buchner|first1=Kirk|title=Interview with Kyle Turley|url=http://www.notinhalloffame.com/home/interviews/4798-interview-with-kyle-turley|accessdate=September 9, 2016|work=Not in Hall of Fame|date=March 19, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Delta Doom On Tour with Crowbar!|url=http://www.gridironrecords.com/delta-doom-on-tour-with-crowbar/|website=Gridiron Records|accessdate=September 9, 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160915110310/http://www.gridironrecords.com/delta-doom-on-tour-with-crowbar/|archive-date=September 15, 2016|dead-url=usurped}}</ref>
====Gridiron Records==== Turley launched Gridiron Records in 2006, along with two of his friends Mike Doling (ex-[[Snot (band)|Snot]] / [[Soulfly]] guitarist) and Tim Pickett (of [[EMI Music]]).<ref>{{cite web|title=Gridiron Records Bio|url=http://www.gridironrecords.com/co_main.html|website=Gridiron Records|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070305090448/http://www.gridironrecords.com/co_main.html|archive-date=March 5, 2007|dead-url=usurped}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Patton|first1=Gregg|title=Turley tackling country rock career|url=http://www.pe.com/articles/turley-631853-music-nfl.html|accessdate=September 9, 2016|work=The Press-Enterprise|date=November 8, 2011}}</ref> Turley and Pickett are the current owners.<ref name="gr contact">{{cite web|title=Contact|url=http://www.gridironrecords.com/contact/|website=Gridiron Records|accessdate=September 8, 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160915051402/http://www.gridironrecords.com/contact/|archive-date=September 15, 2016|dead-url=usurped}}</ref>
In addition to The Kyle Turley Band and Delta Doom, other acts signed to Gridiron Records include [[The Hairbrain Scheme]], Unset, and [[Invitro (band)|Invitro]].<ref name="gr contact" />
===Health issues and advocacy===
====Neurological issues==== Turley has dealt with a number of neurological health issues since retiring from football in 2007. At age 34 he was diagnosed as symptomatic of [[chronic traumatic encephalopathy]] (CTE),<ref>{{cite news|last1=Jacobs|first1=Melissa|title="The United States of Football" director Sean Pamphilon on the concussion epidemic and his own experience with the NFL's power play over ESPN|url=http://thefootballgirl.com/news-and-features/melissas-blog/2013/aug/the-united-states-of-football-director-sean-pamphilon-on-the-concussion-epidemic-and-his-own-experience-with-the-nfls-power-play-over-espn.html|accessdate=September 1, 2016|work=thefootballgirl.com|date=August 23, 2013|archive-url=https://archive.is/Nmwqd|archive-date=September 12, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=United States of Football – Kyle Turley|url=http://theusof.com/bio/characters/kyle-turley|website=theusof.com|accessdate=September 1, 2016}}</ref> and in 2015 he was diagnosed with [[Early-onset Alzheimer's disease|early onset]] of [[Alzheimer's disease]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Letts|first1=Sharon|title=FORTUNE AND PAIN – Kyle Turley, Out Front for the Plant|url=http://www.dopemagazine.com/fortune-and-pain-kyle-turley-out-front-for-the-plant-2/|accessdate=September 1, 2016|work=Dope Magazine|date=February 1, 2016}}</ref> Turley has a seizure disorder,<ref>{{cite news|last1=Breer|first1=Albert|title=Concussion lawsuit: State of things entering Tuesday's hearing|url=http://www.nfl.com/news/story/0ap1000000158376/article/concussion-lawsuit-state-of-things-entering-tuesdays-hearing|accessdate=September 1, 2016|work=nfl.com|date=April 8, 2013}}</ref> suffering a particularly severe episode in 2009 when he blacked out suddenly followed by several hours of slipping in and out of consciousness while seeking treatment in an emergency room.<ref name="yahoo seizure">{{cite news|last1=Silver|first1=Michael|title=Effects of head trauma scaring Turley|url=https://www.yahoo.com/news/effects-head-trauma-scaring-turley-160400232--nfl.html|accessdate=September 1, 2016|work=Yahoo! Sports|date=September 18, 2009}}</ref><ref name="ny seizure">{{cite news|last1=Gladwell|first1=Malcolm|title=OFFENSIVE PLAY – How different are dogfighting and football?|url=http://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2009/10/19/offensive-play|accessdate=September 1, 2016|work=The New Yorker|issue=October 19, 2009}}</ref> Turley also experiences bouts of [[vertigo]], a condition that first appeared during his rookie season but which increased in frequency throughout his career and became a daily occurrence in retirement.<ref>{{cite web|title=One on One with Kyle Turley|url=http://www.concussionconnection.com/kyle-turley/|website=concussionconnection.com|accessdate=September 1, 2016}}</ref> Other symptoms that Turley has dealt with include depression, anxiety, rage issues, suicidal thoughts, migraine headaches, light sensitivity, and memory problems.<ref name="sdut legalize" />
Turley has been active in speaking about his personal experiences dealing with head trauma-related health issues and participating in efforts to reduce risks for current and future players. He testified before Congress in January 2010, giving account of a severe [[concussion]] sustained during the 2003 season and the medical care he received afterwards – noting that team doctors cleared his return to the field three days after being released from the hospital.<ref name="Turley testimony">{{cite web|title=Testimony of Kyle Turley – January 4, 2010,|url=https://judiciary.house.gov/_files/hearings/pdf/Turley100104.pdf|website=judiciary.house.gov|accessdate=September 1, 2016}}</ref> Turley was a plaintiff in a class action lawsuit filed against the NFL seeking medical benefits and compensation for former players suffering from the effects of head trauma,<ref>{{cite news|last1=Strauss|first1=Chris|title=Kyle Turley: Concussion settlement a 'big win'|url=http://ftw.usatoday.com/2013/08/kyle-turley-concussion-settlement-a-big-win|accessdate=September 1, 2016|work=USA Today|date=August 29, 2013}}</ref> initially resulting in a 2013 settlement of $765 million but later amended to allow for a payout expected to exceed $1 billion.<ref>{{cite news|title=Judge OKs 65-year deal over NFL concussions; could cost $1 billion|url=http://espn.go.com/nfl/story/_/id/12742265/judge-oks-65-year-deal-nfl-concussions-cost-1-billion|accessdate=September 3, 2016|work=ESPN|date=April 22, 2015}}</ref> Turley was featured in the 2013 documentary ''United States of Football'' examining issues of neurological health in the NFL and youth league football,<ref>{{cite news|last1=Strauss|first1=Chris|title=Filmmaker on NFL head trauma: 'I didn't want to see any of this'|url=http://ftw.usatoday.com/2013/08/filmmaker-on-nfl-head-trauma-i-didnt-want-to-see-any-of-this|accessdate=September 1, 2016|work=USA Today|date=August 1, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Mikesell|first1=Terry|title='The United States of Football' aims to save sport by scrutinizing its dangers|url=http://www.dispatch.com/content/stories/life_and_entertainment/2013/09/05/director-hopes-to-save-sport-by-scrutinizing-its-dangers.html|accessdate=September 1, 2016|work=The Columbus Dispatch|date=September 5, 2013}}</ref> and has been involved with efforts to educate and assist youth sports programs in head trauma prevention through the Just Cool Me - T.K.O. initiative.<ref>{{cite web|title=T. K. O. – Concussion, Subconcussion, & Migraine Awareness, Education, Treatment, and Recovery|url=http://www.justcoolme.org/tko/|website=justcoolme.org|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160112231703/http://www.justcoolme.org/tko/|archive-date=January 12, 2016}}</ref> Turley has agreed to donate his brain posthumously to the Center for the Study of Traumatic Encephalopathy at [[Boston University]] to help advance research in the area of sports-related neurological disorders.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Barrow|first1=Bill|title=Former New Orleans Saint Kyle Turley joins head trauma research effort|url=http://www.nola.com/saints/index.ssf/2010/02/new_orleans_saints_veteran_kyl.html|accessdate=September 1, 2016|work=The Times-Picayune|date=February 3, 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Kendall|first1=Justin|title=Retired KC Chief Turley donating brain to research|url=http://www.pitch.com/news/article/20578400/retired-kc-chief-turley-donating-brain-to-research|accessdate=September 1, 2016|work=pitch.com|date=October 15, 2009}}</ref>
====Painkiller addiction==== Turley retired from football with an addiction to pain-killing drugs.<ref name="sdut lawsuit">{{cite news|last1=Gehlken|first1=Michael|title=New lawsuit filed against NFL|url=http://www.sandiegouniontribune.com/news/2014/may/20/kyle-turley-nfl-drug-painkiller-lawsuit-goodell/|accessdate=September 1, 2016|work=The San Diego Union-Tribune|date=May 20, 2014}}</ref> He has criticized the manner in which painkillers are dispensed by medical staff in the NFL, stating that pills were handed out to players "like candy" after games.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Nuckols|first1=Ben|title=Ex-players sue NFL over use of painkillers|url=https://www.washingtonexaminer.com/ex-players-sue-nfl-over-use-of-painkillers|accessdate=September 1, 2016|work=Washington Examiner|agency=Associated Press|date=May 20, 2014}}</ref> Turley also says team doctors gave him painkillers while concealing the true nature of a serious back injury in 2003,<ref>{{cite news|last1=Dabe|first1=Christopher|title=Former Saints lineman Kyle Turley continues to speak out about painkiller use in NFL|url=http://www.nola.com/saints/index.ssf/2015/02/kyle_turley_painkillers_video.html|accessdate=September 1, 2016|work=The Times-Picayune|date=February 19, 2015}}</ref> in an effort to keep him on the playing field until season's end.<ref name="cs interview" /> The condition required major surgery in the offseason and eventually led to his release from the Rams,<ref name="cs interview" /> also threatening to end his career at one point.<ref name="espn plagued" /> In 2014, Turley was one of more than 500 former players who took part in a class action lawsuit against the NFL alleging similar complaints,<ref name="sdut lawsuit" /> also charging that team medical personnel neglected to inform players of the serious health risks of the drugs they were taking.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Ley|first1=Tom|title=Retired Stars File Suit Alleging NFL Doped Them Up Like Race Horses|url=http://deadspin.com/retired-stars-file-suit-alleging-nfl-doped-them-up-like-1579045996|accessdate=September 1, 2016|work=Deadspin|date=May 20, 2014}}</ref>
====Medical cannabis==== Turley uses [[Cannabis (drug)|cannabis]] to treat the neurological issues that he suffers from post-NFL career.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Strombel|first1=Tim|title=NFL All-Pro Kyle Turley: Medical cannabis will save football|url=https://www.cashinbis.com/kyle-turley-nfl-all-pro-to-medical-cannabis-advocate/|accessdate=September 23, 2016|work=Cashinbis|date=August 24, 2015}}</ref> He credits cannabis with greatly improving his quality of life and even saving his life,<ref name="sdut legalize">{{cite news|last1=Loh|first1=Stefanie|title=Is it time to legalize marijuana in sports?|url=http://www.sandiegouniontribune.com/sports/aztecs/sdut-marijuana-sports-opioids-arguments-kyle-turley-2015aug01-story.html|accessdate=September 23, 2016|work=The San Diego Union-Tribune|date=August 1, 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160805180755/http://www.sandiegouniontribune.com/news/2015/aug/01/marijuana-sports-opioids-arguments-kyle-turley/all/|archive-date=August 5, 2016|dead-url=no}}</ref> after previously relying on numerous prescription meds with side effects that he says almost drove him to suicide.<ref name="sn marijuana">{{cite news|last1=Heck|first1=Jordan|title=Former NFL player Kyle Turley says marijuana can help with injuries|url=http://www.sportingnews.com/nfl/news/kyle-turley-marijuana-gridiron-cannabis-injury-prevention-concussion/11f9v4n7nab7u15wz0fqktjl7i|accessdate=September 23, 2016|work=Sporting News|date=November 6, 2016}}</ref> Turley completely eliminated his use of pharmaceuticals – including psychiatric and pain-killing drugs – beginning in early 2015 when he went [[cold turkey]] and switched to cannabis only.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Bloom|first1=Steve|title=Kyle Turley Interviewed: "Cannabis Will Save Football"|url=http://www.freedomleaf.com/kyle-turley-interviewed-cannabis-will-save-football/|accessdate=September 23, 2015|work=Freedom Leaf|date=February 2, 2016}}</ref><ref name="vice benefits" /> He has been active in speaking about his personal experience using cannabis, and in 2015 founded the Gridiron Cannabis Coalition to help advance policy change regarding the use of cannabis in professional sports.<ref name="db marijuana">{{cite news|last1=Haglage|first1=Abby|title=Ex-NFL Players Rally Behind Medical Marijuana|url=http://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2016/04/14/ex-nfl-players-rally-behind-medical-marijuana.html|accessdate=September 23, 2016|work=The Daily Beast|date=April 14, 2016}}</ref> The organization is also involved with medical cannabis research, commencing a study in 2016 to examine the effectiveness of cannabis in treating chronic pain and depression.<ref name="db marijuana" />
In November 2016, Turley was among the signatories of an [[open letter]] addressed to the NFL, urging a change in the league's policy towards cannabis.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Jhabvala|first1=Nicki|title=Players, Doctors for Cannabis Regulation pen letter to NFL urging policy reform|url=http://www.denverpost.com/2016/11/11/players-doctors-for-cannabis-regulation-pen-letter-nfl/|accessdate=February 19, 2018|work=The Denver Post|date=November 11, 2016}}</ref> The letter was penned by [[Doctors for Cannabis Regulation]] and signed by several other NFL players.<ref>{{cite news|title=An Open Letter to the National Football League|url=http://dfcr.org/wp-content/uploads/NFL-open-letter.pdf|work=Doctors for Cannabis Regulation|date=November 11, 2016}}</ref> Turley is also a member of the Doctors for Cannabis Regulation NFL steering committee.<ref>{{cite web|title=NFL Steering Committee Members|url=https://dfcr.org/team/|website=Doctors for Cannabis Regulation|accessdate=February 19, 2018}}</ref>
In January 2017, Turley announced the launch of Neuro Armour (now Neuro XPF), a [[Tetrahydrocannabinol|THC]]-free cannabis oil that is rich in [[cannabidiol]] (CBD) and various [[terpene]]s.<ref>{{cite press release|date=January 30, 2017|title=Former NFL All Pro Kyle Turley launches Neuro Armour|url=http://www.prweb.com/releases/2017/01/prweb14024496.htm|location=Houston, TX|agency=PRWeb|access-date=February 2, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite press release|date=January 29, 2018|title=Kyle Turley to bring Neuro XPF CBD to Big Game Week|url=https://www.prlog.org/12689226-kyle-turley-to-bring-neuro-xpf-cbd-to-big-game-week.html|location=Minneapolis, MN|agency=PRLog|access-date=February 2, 2018}}</ref>
====Gridiron Greats==== Turley is a board member and active supporter of the Gridiron Greats Assistance Fund, a non-profit [[501(c) organization#501.28c.29.283.29|501(c)(3) organization]] providing medical care and other forms of assistance to retired NFL players in need.<ref>{{cite web|title=About Gridiron Greats Assistance Fund|url=http://gridirongreats.org/about-us/|website=gridirongreats.org|accessdate=September 6, 2016}}</ref> Turley first became involved as an active player in 2007 when he pledged one of his game checks to the fund and challenged other players to do the same<ref>{{cite news|last1=Johnson|first1=Greg|title=Chiefs' Turley plans to donate to retiree fund|url=http://articles.latimes.com/print/2007/nov/28/sports/sp-nflpension28|accessdate=September 6, 2016|work=Los Angeles Times|date=November 28, 2007}}</ref><ref>{{cite press release|title=NFL Active Player, Kyle Turley, Donates Entire Game Check To Gridiron Greats To Help Retired Players In Need|url=http://www.prweb.com/releases/Kyle_Turley/Nonprofit/prweb572101.htm|location=Chicago, IL|publisher=PRWeb|date=November 27, 2007|access-date=September 6, 2016}}</ref> – many of whom joined in helping to raise several hundred thousand dollars.<ref>{{cite press release|title=NFL Players Coordinate Grassroots Holiday Humanitarian Effort This Sunday|url=http://www.prweb.com/releases/Retired_NFL_Players/Football_Gridiron_Greats/prweb589771.htm|location=Chicago, IL|publisher=PRWeb|date=December 21, 2007|access-date=September 6, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Johnson|first1=Greg|title=Charity effort grows for retired players|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2007/dec/19/sports/sp-nflrep19|accessdate=September 6, 2016|work=Los Angeles Times|date=December 19, 2007}}</ref> Announcing his pledge at a November 2007 press conference,<ref>{{cite news|last1=Marshall|first1=John|title=Emotional Turley putting time, effort and money into assisting former NFL players|url=http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/sports/football/2007-12-18-2801694133_x.htm|accessdate=September 6, 2016|work=USA Today|agency=Associated Press|date=December 18, 2007}}</ref> Turley spoke of the debilitating football-related health problems and inadequate medical / pension benefits that many retired players face,<ref name="usatoday upshaw">{{cite news|last1=O'Keeffe|first1=Michael|title=Chiefs' Kyle Turley criticizes Gene Upshaw for failing retired players|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/sports/football/chiefs-kyle-turley-criticizes-gene-upshaw-failing-retired-players-article-1.258418|accessdate=September 6, 2016|work=New York Daily News|date=November 28, 2007}}</ref> a topic that had already been the focus of two congressional hearings earlier in the year.<ref>{{cite news|last1=O'Keeffe|first1=Michael|title=Chiefs lineman Kyle Turley to donate paycheck to assist retired players|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/sports/football/chiefs-lineman-kyle-turley-donate-paycheck-assist-retired-players-article-1.258429|accessdate=September 6, 2016|work=New York Daily News|date=November 27, 2007}}</ref> Turley became the first active player to publicly take up the cause,<ref>{{cite news|title=Turley challenges active players to give to fund|url=http://www.espn.com/nfl/news/story?id=3129741|accessdate=September 6, 2016|work=ESPN|agency=Associated Press|date=November 27, 2007}}</ref> also taking [[National Football League Players Association|NFLPA]] executive director [[Gene Upshaw]] to task at the time for failing to address the issue.<ref name="usatoday upshaw" /> After retiring from football, Turley continued to raise funding and awareness for Gridiron Greats through his music career, donating a portion of his album sales and concert revenues to the organization.<ref>{{cite press release|title=Two Time NFL All-Pro Turns Rock Star Philanthropist; Kyle Turley on Tour with a Purpose|url=http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/two-time-nfl-all-pro-turns-rock-star-philanthropist-kyle-turley-on-tour-with-a-purpose-129677028.html|location=Chicago, IL|publisher=PRNewswire|date=September 12, 2011|access-date=September 6, 2016}}</ref>
Through his involvement with Gridiron Greats, Turley was instrumental in the development of NFL Life Line, a 24/7 confidential [[crisis hotline]] for current and former NFL players.<ref>{{cite web|title=About the NFL Life Line|url=http://nfllifeline.org/about/|website=nfllifeline.org|accessdate=September 6, 2016}}</ref> Turley conceived of the idea after [[Junior Seau]] committed suicide in May 2012.<ref name="vice benefits">{{cite news|last1=Gordon|first1=Aaron|title=Battle for benefits, Part 1: "Why do I have to fight you now?"|url=https://sports.vice.com/en_us/article/battle-for-benefits-part-1-why-do-i-have-to-fight-you-now|accessdate=September 6, 2016|work=Vice Sports|date=September 16, 2015}}</ref>
===Other=== After living in [[Nashville, Tennessee|Nashville]] for a number of years, Turley and his family moved to [[Riverside, California]] in April 2014, bordering the city of [[Moreno Valley, California|Moreno Valley]] where Turley grew up and attended high school. Turley has helped instruct the [[Arlington High School (California)|Arlington High School]] football team in Riverside, and also hosted a football camp at the school.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Zink|first1=David|title=Former NFL star returning to his roots|url=http://www.pe.com/articles/turley-697406-football-camp.html|accessdate=September 30, 2016|work=The Press-Enterprise|date=July 10, 2014}}</ref>

{{for|the district of Monaco|La Colle, Monaco}} '''La Colle''' ([[floruit|fl]]. 1736 – 1742) was a Monsoni chief who is known in [[History of Canada|Canadian history]] for this period because of the writings of [[Pierre Gaultier de Varennes, sieur de La Vérendrye|La Vérendrye]].
In the fall of 1731, construction began on [[Fort St. Pierre]] at the west end of [[Rainy Lake]] near the mouth of [[Rainy River (Minnesota-Ontario)|Rainy River]]. This was carried out by La Verendrye's nephew, [[Christopher Dufrost de La Jemeraye]] and his eldest son, [[Jean Baptiste de La Vérendrye]] over the winter of 1731-32. La Colle's main village was located in the vicinity of the fort.
La Colle was a chief with influence among the Monsonis, his own group of [[Swampy Cree]], and also with other [[Cree]]s and [[Assiniboine people|Assiniboine]] further west along the exploration route. [[Fort St. Charles]], on [[Lake of the Woods]] was built in 1732, putting the explorer in closer contact with the [[Sioux]]. The La Vérendrye's did not want war between tribes and La Colle was largely able to keep the peace. However, he led at least one war party in 1741 where many Sioux were killed and captured. Father [[Claude-Godefroy Coquart]], who was wintering at [[Fort Kaministiquia]], noted that more slaves than furs would be shipped to [[Montreal]] that season because of this event.
It would appear that La Colle played a significant role in protecting La Vérendrye during his exploration and trade westward.
== External links == * {{cite DCB |first=Harold |last=Hickerson |title=La Colle |volume=3 |url=http://www.biographi.ca/en/bio/la_colle_3E.html}} * [http://www.telusplanet.net/public/dgarneau/metis11.htm Metis Culture 1741-1742]

{{Expand list|date=February 2011}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2016}} [[File:Map of Ireland in Europe.svg|thumb|250px|Location of Ireland]] This is a '''list of notable Irish people''' who were born on the island of [[Ireland]], in either the [[Republic of Ireland]] or [[Northern Ireland]], and have lived there for most of their lives. Also included on the list are people who were not born in Ireland, but have been raised as Irish, have lived there for most of their lives or in regards to the Republic of Ireland, have adopted Irish citizenship (e.g., [[Daniel Day-Lewis]]). The names are sorted by surname.

== Science, education and technology == {{anchor|scientists|engineers|inventors}} * [[Robert Adrain]] (1775–1843) – scientist, mathematician and United Irishman * [[Thomas Andrews (scientist)|Thomas Andrews]] (1813–1885) – chemist and physicist * [[Francis Beaufort]] (1774–1857) – hydrographer, developed a scale for classifying wind strength * [[John Stewart Bell]] (1928–1990) – atomic physicist, 'Bell's Inequalities' * [[John Desmond Bernal]] (1901–1971) – X-ray crystallography * [[George Boole]] (1815–1864) – Boolean Algebra, Digital Logic * [[Robert Boyle]] (1627–1691) – physicist, 'Boyle's law' * [[Louis Brennan]] (1852–1932) – principle of a guided missile, wire-guided torpedo * [[Pádraig de Brún]] (1889–1960) – scholar and mathematician * [[Lucien Bull]] (1876–1972) – high speed photography, modern electrocardiogram (ECG) * [[Jocelyn Bell Burnell]] (born 1943) – discovered [[pulsar]]s * [[Nicholas Callan]] (1799–1864) – inventor of the [[induction coil]] and discoverer the principle of the dynamo * [[Aeneas Coffey]] (1780–1852) – heat exchanger, inventor of the [[column still]] * [[William Monad Crawford]] – [[entomologist]] * [[William Dargan]] – railway [[engineer]] * [[David Doak]] (born 1967) – [[scientist]], [[video game]] developer and [[entrepreneur]] * [[Frederick G. Donnan]] – [[chemist]] * [[Michael Everson]] – expert in [[writing system]]s and [[Unicode]], born in the U.S. * [[Wentworth Erck]] – astronomer, poor-law guardian and magistrate * [[Harry Ferguson]] – engineer, designer of the modern farm tractor, inventor of the three-point hitch * [[George FitzGerald]] (1851–1901) – theoretical physicist, 'FitzGerald-Lorentz Contraction' * [[Patrick Ganly]] (1809–1899) – geologist; described the use of cross-bedding in stratification * [[John Robert Gregg]] (1868–1948) – Gregg shorthand system * [[William Rowan Hamilton]] – mathematician, astronomer and mathematical physicist * [[John Philip Holland]] (1841–1914) – submarine designer * [[Ellen Hutchins]] (1785–1815) – botanist * [[John Joly]] (1857–1933) – photometer, colour photography * [[Richard Kirwan]] (1733–1812) – meteorologist * [[Kathleen Lonsdale]] (1903–1971) – crystallographer * [[Robert Mallet]] (1810–1881) – seismology * [[Alexander Mitchell (engineer)|Alexander Mitchell]] (1780–1868) – lighthouse and marine engineer * [[Hannah Moylan]] (1867-1902), first woman to get a degree in Science in Ireland * [[Robert Murphy (mathematician)|Robert Murphy]] (1806–1843) – mathematician and physicist * [[Richard O'Keefe]] – computer scientist * [[Frank Pantridge]] (1916–2004) – inventor of the mobile defibrillator * [[Dorothy Price]] (1890–1954) – physician who introduced the BCG tuberculosis vaccine to Ireland * [[Sir George Stokes, 1st Baronet]] (1819–1903) – mathematician, physicist, 'Stokes Theorem' and Stokes-Navier Equations' * [[George Johnstone Stoney]] (1826–1911) – atomic physicist, named the electron and measured its charge * [[John Lighton Synge]] (1897–1995) – mathematician * [[William Thomson, 1st Baron Kelvin|William Thomson]], Lord Kelvin (1824–1907) – physicist * [[John Tyndall]] (1820–1893) – physicist * [[Ernest Walton]] (1903–1995) – physicist, 1951 [[Nobel Prize in Physics]] * [[Mary Ward (scientist)|Mary Ward]] (1827–1869) – microscopist * [[John Richardson Wigham]] (1829–1906) – inventor and lighthouse engineer * [[Thomas Wynne]] (1942–2005) – inventor, mechanic and engineer
