{{Use mdy dates|date=October 2013}} {{Use American English|date=July 2018}} {{main|John J. Pershing}} {{Infobox military person | honorific-prefix = [[General of the Army (United States)|General of the Armies]] | name = John J. Pershing | image = General John Joseph Pershing head on shoulders.jpg | caption = | nickname = "Black Jack" |birth_name=John Joseph Pershing | birth_date = {{Birth date|1860|9|13|mf=yes}} | birth_place = [[Laclede, Missouri]], U.S. | death_date = {{Death date and age|1948|7|15|1860|9|13|mf=yes}} | death_place = [[Walter Reed Army Medical Center|Walter Reed General Hospital]]
[[Washington, D.C.]], U.S. | placeofburial = [[Arlington National Cemetery]], Arlington County, Virginia, U.S. | allegiance = [[United States]] | branch = [[United States Army]] | serviceyears = 1886–1924 | rank = [[File:General of Armies insignia.svg|30px]] [[General of the Armies]] | servicenumber = O-1 | unit = | commands = 8th BrigadeWilson, John B. (1999) [https://books.google.com/books?id=Xv6gxzThIMYC&pg=PA35#v=onepage&q&f=false ''Maneuver and Fire Power: The Evolution of Divisions and Separate Brigades''] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180113013544/https://books.google.com/books?id=Xv6gxzThIMYC&pg=PA35 |date=January 13, 2018 }} Washington, D.C.: U.S. Government Printing Office. p. 57 {{ISBN|9780160899447}}Vandiver, v.1 [https://books.google.com/books?id=5Y6hC0s4URYC&pg=PA576 p. 576] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180113013544/https://books.google.com/books?id=5Y6hC0s4URYC&pg=PA576 |date=January 13, 2018 }}
[[Mexican Border Service|Mexican Expedition]]
[[American Expeditionary Forces|American Expeditionary Force]]
[[First United States Army]]
[[Chief of Staff of the United States Army]] | battles = [[Indian Wars]] * [[Apache Wars]] * [[Sioux Wars]] [[Spanish–American War]] * [[Battle of San Juan Hill]] [[Philippine–American War]] * [[Moro Rebellion]] [[Russo-Japanese War]]
[[Mexican Revolution]] * [[Pancho Villa Expedition]] [[World War I]] * [[Western Front (World War I)|Western Front]] | awards = [[Distinguished Service Cross (United States)|Distinguished Service Cross]]
[[Distinguished Service Medal (U.S. Army)|Distinguished Service Medal]]
[[Silver Star]]
Honorary Knight Grand Cross of the [[Order of the Bath]] (United Kingdom)
[[Légion d'honneur]] (France) | relations = | laterwork = | signature = John J Pershing Signature.svg | signature_size = 175 }} [[General of the Armies]] '''John Joseph "Black Jack" Pershing''' (September 13, 1860 – July 15, 1948) was a senior [[United States Army]] [[Officer (armed forces)|officer]]. His most famous post was when he served as the commander of the [[American Expeditionary Forces|American Expeditionary Force]] (AEF) on the [[Western Front (World War I)|Western Front]] in [[World War I]], 1917–18. [[John J. Pershing|Pershing]] was immensely popular after World War I, and as a result a large number of organizations, equipment, streets and buildings are named after him throughout the United States and abroad: ==Organizations== * The National Society of [[Pershing Rifles]], founded by Pershing, continues on today as America's premier undergraduate military fraternal organization. He also founded the [[Military Order of the World Wars]]. * The 2nd Brigade of the [[1st Cavalry Division (United States)]] is nicknamed "Black Jack." * The 4th Squadron of the [[10th Cavalry Regiment (United States)|10th US Cavalry]], part of the [[4th Infantry Division (United States)|4th Infantry Division]]'s 3rd Brigade Combat Team, is nicknamed the Blackjack Squadron * B Troop (Black Jack Troop) 5/15 Cavalry Regiment at [[Fort Knox, Kentucky]], the home of Armor and Cavalry where brand new 19D Cavalry Scouts are trained. A parade field in front of the B Troop barracks is called "Pershing Field" in honor of the General, and a placard of his works lies in its corner. ==Military ordnance and other equipment== * The [[M26 Pershing]] tank was an American armored vehicle introduced in 1945. * The [[Pershing missile]] systems * In 1938, the [[Chicago, Burlington and Quincy Railroad]] named a [[diesel engine]]d [[streamliner]] train the ''[[General Pershing Zephyr]]''. ==Buildings== ===Schools=== ====Elementary schools==== [[Berwyn, Illinois]]; [[Joliet, Illinois]]; [[West Milwaukee, Wisconsin]]; [[Muskogee, Oklahoma]]; [[Lincoln, Nebraska]]; [[Killeen, Texas]] ([[Fort Hood]]); [[Orangevale, California]]; [[Dallas, Texas]]; [[Saint Joseph, Missouri]]; [[Orlando, Florida]]; [[Fort Meade, Maryland]] ====Middle schools==== [[Pershing Middle School (Houston)|Houston, Texas]]; [[Pershing Middle School (Springfield)|Springfield, Missouri]]; [[John J. Pershing Intermediate School 220|Sunset Park, Brooklyn, New York City]]; [[Pershing Middle School (San Diego)|San Diego, California]] ====High schools==== [[Detroit, Michigan]] ===College buildings=== * Pershing Arena, Pershing Society, Pershing Hall, and the Pershing Scholarships of [[Truman State University]] in [[Kirksville, Missouri]] (Pershing's former college) * Pershing Barracks at the [[United States Military Academy]]. Completed in 1895 as the Academic Building for West Point, it was renamed the West Academic Building in 1913. It was later converted to a barracks and renamed Pershing Barracks. * John J. Pershing Military and Naval Science Building of [[University of Nebraska–Lincoln]] * Pershing Hall{{cite web |url=http://www.msun.edu/aboutmsun/history/pershing.htm |title=MSU-Northern: 75th Anniversary |publisher=Msun.edu |date= |accessdate=2014-04-28 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140429044238/http://www.msun.edu/aboutmsun/history/pershing.htm |archivedate=April 29, 2014 |df=mdy-all }} of [[Montana State University – Northern]] in [[Havre, Montana]] * Pershing Hall, part of the [[University of Missouri]], [[Columbia, Missouri]] * Pershing Walk, a campus street at [[Culver Military Academy]], [[Culver, Indiana]] ===Military buildings=== * Pershing Hall in [[The Presidio of San Francisco]] in [[San Francisco]], [[California]][http://www.innatthepresidio.com/accommodations/main-building-42 "Pershing Hall, The Inn's Main Building"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170101091040/http://www.innatthepresidio.com/accommodations/main-building-42 |date=January 1, 2017 }} The Inn at the Presidio website * Pershing Hall on [[Governors Island]] in [[New York Harbor]] * Pershing Community Center, [[Fort Leonard Wood (military base)|Fort Leonard Wood]], [[Missouri]]{{cite web |url=http://www.fortleonardwoodmwr.com/pershing.php |title=Pershing Community Center |publisher=Fortleonardwoodmwr.com |date= |accessdate=2014-04-28 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140429080440/http://www.fortleonardwoodmwr.com/pershing.php |archivedate=April 29, 2014 |df=mdy-all }} * [[Pershing House]] in [[Fort Sam Houston]], [[San Antonio]], [[Texas]] ===Other buildings=== * The [[Pershing Center]], a multi-purpose arena in downtown [[Lincoln, Nebraska]] * The Pershing Building in [[Kansas City, Missouri]], located on Pershing Road * The John J. Pershing VA Medical Center, in [[Poplar Bluff, Missouri]].[http://www.poplarbluff.va.gov/ John J Pershing VA Medical Center website] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120629164947/http://www.poplarbluff.va.gov/ |date=June 29, 2012 }} * Pershing Memorial Hospital in Brookfield Missouri * The [[Pershing Hall]] in Paris, France. * Pershing Memorial Hospital in Brookfield, Missouri ==Places== ===Streets=== * Pershing or General Pershing Avenue: [[St. Louis, Missouri]] (previously known as Berlin Avenue); [[Fort Riley, Kansas]]; [[Phoenix, Arizona]]; [[Cleveland, Ohio]]; [[San Diego, California]]; [[Stockton, California]]; [[Orlando, Florida]]; [[San Jose, California]]; [[Orangevale, California]]; [[Ocean Springs, Mississippi]]; [[Fort Worth, Texas]]; [[Rensselaer, New York]]; [[Milltown, New Jersey]]; [[Lancaster, Pennsylvania]]; [[Salem, Ohio]] ** ''Avenida General Pershing'' in the [[San Isidro District, Lima|San Isidro District]] of [[Lima]], [[Peru]] * Pershing or General Pershing [[Boulevard]]: [[North Little Rock, Arkansas]], [[Oklahoma City, Oklahoma]] (on the [[Oklahoma State Fairgrounds]], formerly part of Main Street); [[Cheyenne, Wyoming]] (a main road to [[Warren AFB]]); [[Kenosha, Wisconsin]] ** ''Boulevard Pershing'' on the western edge of [[Paris]], [[France]] runs past the [[Palais des congrès de Paris|Palais des Congrès]] near the [[Porte Maillot]]. Many of the major streets in the area (the [[16th arrondissement of Paris|16th arrondissement]]) are named after notable French military figures, including [[Avenue Foch]], named after [[Marshall Foch|Marshal Foch]], and at either end of Boulevard Pershing, streets named after the [[Marshal of France|Marshals of France]] [[Laurent, Marquis de Gouvion Saint-Cyr|Gouvion Saint-Cyr]] and [[Marie Pierre Koenig|Koenig]]. It reflects the immense popularity of the American troops who first arrived in the French capital in 1916. ** ''Boulevard John-Joseph Pershing'' in [[Limpertsberg]], [[Luxembourg]] * Pershing or General Pershing Drive: [[El Paso, Texas]]; [[North Omaha, Nebraska]]; [[Florence, Nebraska]]; [[Arlington, Virginia]]; [[Arlington National Cemetery]]; [[El Segundo, California|El Segundo]]/[[Playa del Rey, California]]; [[Decatur, Illinois]]; [[Derby, Connecticut]]; [[Silver Spring, Maryland]] * [[Pershing Road (Weehawken)]] in [[Weehawken, New Jersey]] * Pershing or General Pershing Road: [[Pershing Road (Chicago)|Chicago]] (formerly 39th Street); [[Kansas City, Missouri]] (the northern border to the [[Liberty Memorial]], the Official National World War I Memorial); [[Fort Bliss, Texas]] * Pershing or General Pershing Street: [[Houston]]; [[New Orleans]] (in the uptown section); [[Hammond, Louisiana]]; Portland, Oregon; [[Cranston, Rhode Island]] ===Squares and plazas=== * Pershing Point in [[Atlanta]] * [[Pershing Square (Los Angeles)|Pershing Square]] in [[downtown Los Angeles]] * Pershing Square in [[New York City]] on [[42nd Street (Manhattan)|42nd Street]] at [[Park Avenue (Manhattan)|Park Avenue]] in front of [[Grand Central Terminal]] * Plaza Pershing in [[Zamboanga City]], [[Philippines]] ===Parks=== * [[Pershing Field]] Memorial Park in [[Jersey City]], New Jersey (opened in 1922) * [[Pershing Park]] in Washington, D.C. features the Pershing Memorial[http://www.dcmemorials.com/index_indiv0000642.htm Pershing Memorial] * Pershing State Park, in north-central [[Missouri]] between [[Laclede, Missouri|Laclede]] and [[Meadville, Missouri|Meadville]] * Pershing Park in [[Minneapolis, Minnesota]], [[Racine, Wisconsin]] and [[Arkansas City, Kansas]] * Pershing Field in [[Fort Carson, Colorado]] * [[Stade Pershing]], a baseball park in [[Paris, France]] ===Other places=== * [[Pershing County]], [[Nevada]] * [[Mount Pershing]], in the [[Olympic Mountains]] of [[Washington (state)]] ==Miscellany== * A [[riderless horse]] was named in honor of Pershing, "[[Black Jack (horse)|Black Jack]]". This horse was used for many years in funerals for heads of state, including President [[John F. Kennedy]]. * The Pershing Division of the Clarence Cannon Conference, a high school athletic conference in Northeastern Missouri in the area where the general lived during his youth. The other division in the conference honors [[Harry S. Truman]]. * The John J. Pershing Grille is a casual dining room at the [[University Club of Washington, DC]]. Pershing, a member of the Club, dedicated its current clubhouse, located at 1135 Sixteenth Street, in 1921. * The [[Great Pershing Balloon Derby]] at [[Brookfield, Missouri]] is named in his honor and is held over the [[Labor Day]] weekend each year. * General Pershing, a British racehorse that took part in the [[1995 Grand National]] Steeplechase. ==References== {{reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Pershing, {{Use mdy dates|date=May 2014}} {{Infobox musical artist | name = Martie Maguire | background = non_vocal_instrumentalist | image = Martie Maguire in 2010.jpg | caption = Erwin playing at SXSW, Austin, Texas in 2010 | birth_name = Martha Elenor Erwin | alias = Martie Seidel, Martie Maguire | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1969|10|12}} | birth_place = [[York, Pennsylvania]], U.S. | death_date = | genre = [[Alternative country]], [[Country music|country]], [[Bluegrass music|bluegrass]], [[country rock]], [[Folk music|folk]] | occupation = Musician, songwriter, record producer, [[Arrangement|arranger]] | instrument = Violin, [[viola]], acoustic guitar, double bass, [[mandolin]], mandocaster, backing vocals, [[fiddle]] | years_active = 1989–present | label = [[Sony BMG Music Entertainment|SonyBMG]], [[Sony Music Entertainment|Open Wide]], [[Columbia Records|Columbia]] | associated_acts = [[Dixie Chicks]], [[Court Yard Hounds (band)|Court Yard Hounds]] | website = [http://www.dixiechicks.com DixieChicks.com]
[http://www.courtyardhounds.com CourtYardHounds.com] }} '''Martha "Martie" Elenor Erwin''' (before '''Maguire'''; born October 12, 1969) is an American musician who is a founding member of both the female [[alternative country]] band, [[Dixie Chicks]] and country bluegrass duo, [[Court Yard Hounds]]. She won awards in national fiddle championships while still a teenager. Erwin is accomplished on several other instruments, including the mandolin, viola, double bass and guitar. She has written and co-written a number of the band's songs, some of which have become chart-topping hits. She also contributes her skills in vocal harmony and backing vocals, as well as orchestrating string arrangements for the band. Erwin learned several instruments at a young age, honing her skills with her younger sister, [[Emily Strayer]] (born Emily Erwin) and two schoolmates (a brother and sister team, Troy and [[Sharon Gilchrist]]) for over five years as a part of a touring bluegrass quartet while in high school. After graduation, the sisters forged an alliance with two other women they had met through the Dallas music scene, [[Laura Lynch]] and [[Robin Lynn Macy]], forming a bluegrass and country music band, [[busking]] and touring the bluegrass festival circuits for six years. After the departure of Macy, and the replacement of Lynch with singer [[Natalie Maines]], the band widened their musical repertoire and appearance. The result was a trio so commercially successful that it took the country music industry by surprise, with a number of hit songs, albums, and awards that have set records in the music industry. Erwin subsequently stood by her bandmates as they were engulfed in political controversy. ==Early life== Martha Elenor Erwin, nicknamed Martie, was born October 12, 1969, in [[York, Pennsylvania]],{{cite web|url=http://www.tvguide.com/celebrities/martie-maguire/256027 |title=Martie Maguire News, Martie Maguire Bio and Photos |publisher=TVGuide.com |date= |accessdate=2014-07-15}} to Barbara Trask and Paul Erwin. She was raised in [[Addison, Texas|Addison]], a northern suburban town on the edge of [[Dallas, Texas|Dallas]], [[Texas]]. She has an elder sister, Julia Erwin-Weiner, born in 1967, her younger sister and band member [[Emily Robison|Emily Strayer]], born in 1972 and younger half-brother, R&B singer Ian Davis, born in 1996. Encouraged by her parents – educators at private schools – Erwin began playing violin at age five, and by age 12, started to learn to play "[[fiddle]] style" after receiving a birthday gift of fiddle lessons.[http://www.lhj.com/lhj/story.jhtml?storyid=/templatedata/lhj/story/data/martiemaguirecelebprofile_01132003.xml ]{{dead link|date=July 2014}} She also was active in her school orchestra.[http://www.freewebs.com/originalchicks/newsarchive.htm] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071219045902/http://www.freewebs.com/originalchicks/newsarchive.htm |date=December 19, 2007 }} Her sister Emily shared her love and interest in music, and displayed early talent herself. The two sisters were provided musical instruction on several instruments, and their talent for [[vocal harmony]] continued to be nurtured. Although Erwin became famous for her harmony and mastery of the fiddle, she also plays a variety of [[String instrument|strings]] that include the [[viola]], guitar, [[mandolin]], and double bass.Leggett, Steve [http://music.msn.com/artist/?artist=16649328&menu=bio All-Music Guide writer on MSN]{{dead link|date=November 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} (Retrieved March 9, 2008) Erwin [[Composer|compose]]s songs and [[arrangement|arrange]]s the use of [[stringed instrument]]s for concert and recording performances. ==Early career== By 1983, Erwin was touring with her sister Emily and school friends; siblings Troy and [[Sharon Gilchrist]].{{cite web|url=http://www.jambase.com/Artists/Bio.aspx?ArtistID=29795 |title=Sharon Gilchrist Bio, History, Info on JamBase |publisher=Jambase.com |date= |accessdate=2014-07-15}} The sisters showed an "almost obsessive" interest in [[busking]] at small venues and attending bluegrass festivals.Frost, Jane [http://www.dixie-chicks.com/stories.shtml Walnut Valley Festival in Winfield, KS, Early 1980s The All-Inclusive Dixie Chicks Page] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151002000000/http://www.dixie-chicks.com/stories.shtml |date=October 2, 2015 }} The four students formed the teenage [[bluegrass music|bluegrass]] group "Blue Night Express", playing together for five years, from 1984–1989,Gilchrist, Sharon [http://homepage.ntlworld.com/farawayhills/sharon_gilchrist.html Faraway Hills Retrieved 12 February, 2008] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303182257/http://homepage.ntlworld.com/farawayhills/sharon_gilchrist.html |date=March 3, 2016 }} while still attending private [[Greenhill School (Addison, Texas)|Greenhill School]]. "We'd drive down to the west end of Dallas and open our cases, and that was our job", Erwin said of it in a later interview to [[60 Minutes II]] [[correspondent]] [[Dan Rather]]. "That's how we made money in high school."Rather, Dan 60 Minutes II [http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2000/10/23/60II/main243501.shtml?source=search_story Dixie Chicks Not Whistling Dixie The Trio Has Sold 17 Million CDs] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131016114544/http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2000/10/23/60II/main243501.shtml?source=search_story |date=October 16, 2013 }} September 6, 2002 Retrieved June 26, 2008 Also while in high school Erwin performed at Six Flags Over Texas in Arlington, TX, in a strolling duo with Troy Gilchrist for a summer. In 1987, Erwin was awarded second place for the fiddle in the National fiddle championships held yearly in [[Winfield, Kansas]]. Upon graduation from high school, with Emily still in high school, she spent a year attending college at [[Southwestern University]] in [[Georgetown, Texas]], from 1988–1989. She performed in the school orchestra there and again competed in the national fiddle championships at the [[Walnut Valley Festival]], in Winfield, earning third place that year.{{cite web|url=http://www.wvfest.com/ |title=Walnut Valley Festival - Winfield, Kansas |publisher=Wvfest.com |date= |accessdate=2014-07-15}} In the 90s she played occasionally with the [[slo-core]] band, [[Bedhead (band)|Bedhead]].http://ovrld.com/interviews/interview-underground-legend/ ==Dixie Chicks== [[File:Martie Maguire by ViVr.jpg|thumb|left| Erwin at [[Royal Albert Hall]], 2003]] In 1989, Erwin and Strayer joined guitarist [[Robin Lynn Macy]] and [[Laura Lynch]] on double bass in the [[Dixie Chicks]], playing what was at the time predominantly [[bluegrass music]] and a mix of [[Country music|country]] standards. Originally listed as Martha, and then Martie Erwin, Erwin played [[fiddle]], [[mandolin]], [[viola]] and [[Harmony|harmonized]] with Strayer on backing vocals.{{cite web|url=http://www.superiorpics.com/martie_maguire/ |title=The Martie Maguire Picture Pages |publisher=Superiorpics.com |date= |accessdate=2014-07-15}} Erwin had begun writing and recording songs on their debut independent album, ''[[Thank Heavens for Dale Evans]]'', and in 2001, one song co-written with Laura Lynch called "Pink Toenails" resurfaced. The song was featured in the film, ''[[Don't Say A Word]]'', with [[Skye McCole Bartusiak]] performing the song.(Retrieved March 22, 2008)[https://movies.yahoo.com/movie/1807438736/cast#Music Yahoo Movie Review for Don't Say a Word] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110522135843/http://movies.yahoo.com/movie/1807438736/cast#Music |date=May 22, 2011 }} When their second album had a more polished sound, Erwin commented, "I hope our fans won't be disappointed [in ''The Little Ol' Cowgirl'']; it's got drums on every track; it's no longer bluegrass, but we have to make a living and you can't do that playing bluegrass."Clark, Renee [http://www.dixie-chicks.com/dlife392.shtml Can the Dixie Chicks make it in the big time? Local Heroes (Transcribed from) ''Dallas Life Magazine'', ''Dallas Morning News'', March 1, 1992] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304191833/http://www.dixie-chicks.com/dlife392.shtml |date=March 4, 2016 }}(Retrieved January 23, 2008) Two albums later, after [[Natalie Maines]] assumed the position of vocalist, the band was revitalized. Erwin said of their music, "It's very rootsy, but then Natalie comes in with a rock and blues influence. That gave Emily and I{{sic}} a chance to branch out, because we loved those kinds of music but felt limited by our instruments."{{cite web|url=http://chickoholic.tripod.com/DixieChicks/id8.html |title=Martie Maguire |publisher=Chickoholic.tripod.com |date= |accessdate=2014-07-15}} [[File:Martie Maguire in Austin, Texas.jpg|thumb|220px|right|Martie Erwin with the Dixie Chicks in Austin, TX, 2006]] Erwin co-wrote the song, "[[Cowboy Take Me Away]]" on the Chicks sophomore studio album ''[[Fly (Dixie Chicks album)|Fly]]'' for her sister Emily. It was a tribute to Emily's [[courtship]] with [[country music]] writer/singer [[Charlie Robison]]. Erwin was singled out by [[Broadcast Music, Incorporated|BMI]] in 2000, and awarded Songwriter of the Year for writing and/or co-writing "[[Cowboy Take Me Away]]", "Ready To Run" and "[[You Were Mine]]". "You Were Mine" was co-written by the sisters about their parents' divorce.Hillman, Chris [http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,84675,00.html Entertainment Weekly] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140429044300/http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0%2C%2C84675%2C00.html |date=April 29, 2014 }} (Retrieved April 21, 2008) In 1999, the Dixie Chicks performed two songs, recording a [[Cover song|cover]] of the song, "[[You Can't Hurry Love]]" as well as Erwin's "[[Ready to Run (Dixie Chicks song)|Ready to Run]]" for the [[Julia Roberts]]/ [[Richard Gere]] film ''[[Runaway Bride (1999 film)|Runaway Bride]]''. In 2003, Erwin was nominated for a [[Tony Award]] for co-composing the [[film score]] to ''[[Urban Cowboy (musical)|Urban Cowboy]]''; the musical used her "[[Cowboy Take Me Away]]".[http://www.frontpagepublicity.com/dxc/content/careeroverview.html] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080226165207/http://www.frontpagepublicity.com/dxc/content/careeroverview.html |date=February 26, 2008 }} After the band achieved massive commercial success with its first Sony studio two albums with Maines, they struggled with their record company over artistic direction on the third. Erwin commented, "I don't think any of us ever trusted Nashville. When you're in that town you know everybody is talking about everybody else. Everybody is wishing for the other guy to fail."Martie Maguire, to ''[[The Los Angeles Times]]'', 5/21/06. Flippo, Chet (May 25, 2006) [http://www.cmt.com/news/nashville-skyline/1532532/nashville-skyline-dixie-chicks-dixie-chicks-dixie-chicks.jhtml CMT News Nashville Skyline: Dixie Chicks, Dixie Chicks, Dixie Chicks] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140407062651/http://www.cmt.com/news/nashville-skyline/1532532/nashville-skyline-dixie-chicks-dixie-chicks-dixie-chicks.jhtml |date=April 7, 2014 }} Although Erwin and Strayer often appear quiet and demure compared to their animated bandmate Natalie Maines, the trio have stood united on controversial subjects since they banded together to play in 1995, even when their opinions have had the potential to serve them more harm than good. In 2006, Erwin said, "I'd rather have a smaller following of really cool people who get it, who will grow with us as we grow and are fans for life, than people that have us in their five-disc changer with [[Reba McEntire]] and [[Toby Keith]]. We don't want those kinds of fans. They limit what you can do."{{cite news | author=Tryangiel, Josh |url=http://www.time.com/time/archive/preview/0,10987,1196419,00.html |title=In The Line of Fire|date=May 29, 2006|publisher=''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]''}} ===Court Yard Hounds=== [[File:Martie-Maguire 2010.jpg|thumb|200px|Erwin performing at [[Clifford Antone|Antone's]] in Austin, with the [[Court Yard Hounds]]; March 18, 2010]] With Natalie Maines taking a break from music, Erwin was working on a solo fiddle album; however, it was announced in January 2010 that she and sister [[Emily Strayer]] have formed a side project called the [[Court Yard Hounds (band)|Court Yard Hounds]], with Strayer on lead vocals.{{cite web|url=http://www.dixiechickshenhouse.com/ |title=Dixie Chicks Henhouse |publisher=Dixiechickshenhouse.com|accessdate=2014-07-15}}{{cite web|url=http://www.countrystandardtime.com/news/newsitem.asp?xid=2485 |title=Dixie Chicks Martie Maguire records |publisher=Countrystandardtime.com |date=2007-10-23 |accessdate=2014-07-15}} The band made their live debut in March at [[South by Southwest]] with an album released in May 2010.{{cite web|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/rockdaily/index.php/2010/01/15/dixie-chicks-plan-album-tour-with-court-yard-hounds-side-project/ |title=Which Band Will Reunite Next? Placing Odds on 14 Groups, from Led Zeppelin to N'Sync Pictures |publisher=Rolling Stone |date= |accessdate=2014-07-15}} ==Personal life== Martie married [[pharmaceutical]] [[sales representative|representative]] Ted Seidel on June 17, 1995, and changed her last name to Seidel. She also was stepmother to his son, Carter. However, her marriage did not last, and she and Ted Seidel were divorced in November 1999. At bandmate [[Natalie Maines]]' sister Kim's wedding Martie met Gareth Maguire, a [[Roman Catholic]] teacher and actor from [[Northern Ireland]]. The couple became engaged in June 2001 and married on August 10, 2001, in a civil ceremony in Hawaii; as explained at one of their concerts, the Dixie Chicks' song "[[White Trash Wedding]]" is based on Martie's relationship with Gareth.{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=EshGQDYBKyE |title=An evening with The Dixie Chicks - White Trash Wedding |publisher=YouTube |date=2008-11-25 |accessdate=2014-07-15}} Later they had a Catholic "blessing" ceremony in the groom's hometown, [[Carnlough]] in [[County Antrim]], [[Northern Ireland]], on March 9, 2002, for all the guests that were not able to attend the first wedding. Martie said of the ceremony that the [[Catholic Church]] would not permit a wedding service due to her prior divorce. Erwin said that there were many "special" people that they'd wanted to include, but that they just couldn't wait to marry.CMT Online [http://www.cmt.com/artists/news/1449170/09252001/dixie_chicks.jhtml CMT Online (Retrieved 25 September, 2005)] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090212233741/http://www.cmt.com/artists/news/1449170/09252001/dixie_chicks.jhtml |date=February 12, 2009 }} Another reason for the rush was Gareth's need to keep flying back and forth between the United States and Ireland because of visa considerations.Minchin III, James R. and Lieberman, Ellen InStyle Magazine; February 2003, Vol. 10 Issue 2, pg. 244 Retrieved September 25, 2005 After her second marriage, Martie changed her name to that of her new husband, which is why in her musical career she has had the [[surnames]] of Erwin, Seidel, and Maguire. They had three daughters together: [[fraternal twins]] Eva Ruth and Kathleen 'Katie' Emilie were born April 27, 2004. Katie was named after Gareth's late sister, Kathleen.Martie Maguire's twin daughters and Natalie Maines' sons [http://celebritybabies.people.com/2007/01/01/martie_maguires/ [[People (magazine)|People]] (Retrieved June 28, 2012)] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161011231842/http://celebritybabies.people.com/2007/01/01/martie_maguires/ |date=October 11, 2016 }} Third daughter Harper Rosie Maguire was born July 25, 2008. They divorced in 2013.[http://moviepilot.com/posts/3946327 On Tour Again Today, But What Do They Look Like Now?] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161011225726/http://moviepilot.com/posts/3946327 |date=October 11, 2016 }} Erwin has been frank about using [[invitro fertilization]] to conceive their daughters. In an interview in ''[[Conceive (magazine)|Conceive]]'', she said, "All my paperwork said 'unspecified origin.' We spent three years of active trying before we went to IVF. First I went on [[Clomid]]. Then I had some dye tests and found I had a collapsed tube, so I had [[laparoscopic surgery]]; the tube wasn't blocked, just spasming." After three attempts at [[intrauterine insemination]], she said, she and her husband didn't think it was worth continuing in that manner, and switched to [[IVF]].{{cite web|url=http://www.conceiveonline.com/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=71&Itemid=22 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090206171500/http://www.conceiveonline.com/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=71&Itemid=22 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=February 6, 2009 |title=The Dixie Chicks: Taking the Long Way ... to Motherhood |last=Weinhouse, |first=Beth |date=Fall 2007 |publisher=Conceive Magazine Online |accessdate=2008-07-27 |df= }} In August 2007, Maguire began IVF again, resulting in their third daughter Harper. Regarding the number of children the Dixie Chicks have produced in the past seven years, (Maines has two; Strayer has four in addition to Erwin's twins and newborn) Erwin told ''[[People (magazine)|People]]'', "We'll have to move over and let the little chicks take over! We've got a new band!"''People Magazine'' (accessed January 28, 2008)[http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,20174066,00.html Dixie Chick Martie Maguire Is Expecting] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160914183801/http://www.people.com/people/article/0%2C%2C20174066%2C00.html |date=September 14, 2016 }} Erwin and Strayer co-wrote a song, "So Hard", about their own personal experiences with infertility and their need to rely on other methods to conceive. They speak out about the difficulties they faced, but also their good fortune; both having options that for many women are financially prohibitive. Mentioning the [[social stigma|stigma]] attached to IVF, Erwin said, "I think we feel a responsibility to break down some barriers. It's much more of a common problem than people realize."Frontpage Publicity [http://www.frontpagepublicity.com/dxc/bio.html Dixie Chicks Website] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151017015925/http://www.frontpagepublicity.com/dxc/bio.html |date=October 17, 2015 }} A final concern Erwin mentioned was the question of what to do with all the unused frozen [[embryos]].
Now that I have children, I see those embryos as possible children. So I have to think about what my options are if there are leftovers again. I could keep them in storage, and maybe they will help my children some day. Or I can try to donate them to [[stem cell research]]. I don't think I could give them to another family. I would always worry: what if it's an abusive family? What if they don't get enough love?{{dead link|date=April 2014}}
Natalie Maines has said she and Erwin learned [[Transcendental Meditation technique|Transcendental Meditation]] in the mid-1990s.{{cite web|last=Willman|first=Chris|title=Dixie Chicks, Russell Simmons Meditate on Rick Rubin's Greatness at David Lynch Foundation Event|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/dixie-chicks-russell-simmons-meditate-684492|accessdate=April 27, 2014|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6P9PfF1jY?url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/dixie-chicks-russell-simmons-meditate-684492|archivedate=April 27, 2014|quote=Maines is a TM-er, it turns out. Eighteen years ago, she told the crowd, she and fiddler Martie Erwin went to learn TM together}} ===Awards=== {{Further|List of awards and nominations received by Dixie Chicks}} ===Discography=== {{main|Dixie Chicks discography}} * Erwin played fiddle on the song, "Somewhere Down The Road" on the [[eponymous]] album, ''[[Deryl Dodd]]'' by [[Deryl Dodd]] on Sony. * Erwin also played fiddle on [[The Flatlanders]]' adaptation of [[Woody Guthrie]]'s "Sowing on the Mountain" on their 2009 album ''Hills and Valleys.'' * As part of the [[Court Yard Hounds]], Erwin played fiddle and provided harmony vocals on the song "She Sang Hymns Out Of Tune" on the ''[[Cass County (album)|Cass County]]'' album by [[Don Henley]]. ==References== {{Reflist|colwidth=30em}} ==External links== {{Commons {{Infobox Governor General | name=Martín García Óñez de Loyola | image=Martin Garcia Oñez de Loyola.JPG | order=[[Royal Governor of Chile]] | term_start=1592 | term_end=1598 | monarch=[[Philip II of Spain|Philip II]] | primeminister= | predecessor=[[Pedro de Viscarra de la Barrera]] | successor=[[Pedro de Viscarra de la Barrera]] | birth_date=c. 1549 | birth_place=[[Azpeitia]], [[Gipuzkoa]], [[Spain]] | death_date=December 24, 1598 | death_place=[[Disaster of Curalaba|Curalaba]], [[Chile]] | spouse=Beatriz Clara Coya | children= | profession= | religion=[[Catholic]] <!--Military service--> |nickname = |allegiance = {{flag|Spanish Empire|name=Spain}} |branch = |serviceyears = 1530s–1563 |rank = |unit = |commands = |battles = [[Arauco War]] *[[Battle of Curalaba]] |awards = |}} '''[[Don (honorific)|Don]] Martín García Óñez de Loyola''' (1549 in [[Azpeitia]], [[Gipuzkoa]] – December 24, 1598 at [[Disaster of Curalaba|Curalaba]]) was a [[Spain|Spanish]] [[Basque people|Basque]] soldier and [[Royal Governor of Chile|Royal Governor]] of the [[Captaincy General of Chile]].
==Early life== As a young man in 1568, he arrived in [[Peru]] at the side of the new [[viceroy]] [[Francisco de Toledo, Count of Oropesa]], as captain of the guard. In 1572, during the military expedition against [[Tupac Amaru]]- the last descendant of the [[Incas]] resisting foreign domination - Oñez de Loyola lead a brilliant action of an advance column which fell upon the camp of the Inca and captured him.
For this great feat, he gained the rank of ''[[corregidor (position)|corregidor]]'' in a number of Peruvian towns, entitling him to their goods and labor. He was also rewarded with a wife, a member of the royal Incan house and niece of Tupac Amaru. She was baptized with the Christian name Beatriz Clara Coya.
With these recommendations, the king named him governor of [[Paraguay]] in 1592. However, just before he assumed the position, [[Philip II of Spain|Philip II]] designated him [[Royal Governor of Chile]], as he was considered the officer most apt to finish the [[War of Arauco]].
==Governor of Chile== [[File:Quiñones, Oñes de Loyola y Viscarra.JPG|thumb|left|200px|Alonso de Ovalle's 1646 engraving of [[Francisco de Quiñónez|Quiñones]], Oñez de Loyola and [[Pedro de Viscarra|Viscarra]]]]
Oñez de Loyola arrived in Chile on September 23, 1592. He was determined to pacify the Arauco. To further this end he immediately set out for [[Concepción, Chile|Concepción]] at the head of 110 troops which he had met at the capital. However, he realized that with such scarce resources he would not be able to achieve his objective and he requested reinforcements from Peru.
However, the appearance of the [[British people|British]] pirate [[Richard Hawkins]] alarmed the authorities in Peru and their reinforcements were recalled for the defense of Peru itself. Hawkins also attacked Chile during his campaigns, assaulting [[Valparaiso]], for example where he captured a ship. Because of the limited capacity of his ship, he only took things he needed and let the captured sailors go free.
The governor did not receive the requested soldiers, but members of the [[Jesuit]] and [[Augustinians|Augustinian]] orders did arrive. The first would have great importance for later events in the colonization of Chile, until they were eventually expelled.
The governor decided that he could not wait any longer and in 1594 he began a campaign to the south with the small contingent that he had assembled. He founded a fort at [[Santa Cruz de Oñez]] in May 1594, near the confluence of the Bio-Bio and Laja Rivers in [[Catiray]], where gold mines were located on the [[Rele River]]. The fort was elevated to the rank of city in 1595 giving it the name of [[Santa Cruz de Coya]].
Three years later a group of 140 reinforcements arrived, but they were not enough. The lack of reinforcements was not the fault of the viceroy — who offered generous inducements to join the army — but rather the name of Chile, which had become so stained by the interminable conflict that no one wanted to risk their lives going to such a hell.
==Death== {{main|Battle of Curalaba}} The governor was in [[La Imperial, Chile|La Imperial]] when news arrived that the [[Mapuche]]s had renewed their attacks against [[Angol]]. In order to reinforce this point, he set out with 50 men on December 21, 1598. On the second day of the march they arrived at a place called ''Curallaba'' or ''Curalava'' (the broken rock), on the banks of the [[Lumaco River]], where they rested without taking any precautions against attack. On the nights of the 23rd and 24th the natives approached the camp, and with shouts and the sounds of horns they attacked the Spanish.
Oñez de Loyola and a pair of soldiers at his side fought very valiantly, but finally succumbed to the spears of the natives. In the melee almost all the Spaniards died, save a cleric named Bartolomé Pérez, who was taken prisoner, and a soldier named Bernardo de Pereda, who received 23 wounds on his body and was left for dead but improbably survived.
The Mapuches then initiated a general uprising which destroyed all the cities in their homeland south of the [[Biobío River]]. They kept the head of Oñez de Loyola, giving it back years later to the governor [[Alonso García de Ramón]].
{{commons category|Martín García Óñez de Loyola}}

{{Use dmy dates|date=November 2017}} {{Infobox person | name = MaryJane Mwangi | image = | image_size = | caption = | birth_date = | birth_place = [[Kenya]] | death_date = | death_place = | residence = [[Nairobi]], [[Kenya]] | nationality = Kenyan | citizenship = Kenya | alma_mater = '''[[University of Nairobi]]'''
'''[https://www.ihrm.or.ke/ Institute of Human Resource Management]''' | occupation = [[Corporate Executive]] | years_active = 1990 — present | known_for = | home_town = | title = [[Chief Executive Officer]] of the [[National Oil Corporation of Kenya]] | spouse = {{small|'''Martin Mbogo'''}} | ethnicity = | networth = | religion = }} '''MaryJane Mwangi''', also '''Mary Jane Mwangi''', is a [[corporate executive]] in [[Kenya]], who serves as the [[managing director]] and [[chief executive officer]] of the [[National Oil Corporation of Kenya]], since August 2017.{{cite web|accessdate=3 November 2017 |url=http://www.businessdailyafrica.com/corporate/companies/National-Oil-acting-chief-executive-confirmed/4003102-4047742-1uemiqz/index.html | title=National Oil acting chief executive confirmed | last=Herbling | newspaper=[[Business Daily Africa]] |publisher=[[Nation Media Group]] | date=6 August 2017 |location=Nairobi | first=David}} ==Background and education== She graduated from the [[University of Nairobi]] with a [[Master of Business Administration]] degree in 2006. She also holds a [[Human resource management|Higher Diploma in Human Resource Management]], awarded in 2013, by the Institute of Human Resource Management (IHRM), based in [[Nairobi]], Kenya's capital and largest city.{{cite web| url=https://www.linkedin.com/in/maryjane-mwangi-576a5a11a/?trk=public-profile-join-page |title=MaryJane Mwangi: National Oil Corporation of Kenya |accessdate=3 November 2017 |date= 2016 |publisher=Linkedin Webpage of MryJane Mwangi |last=Mwangi |first=MaryJane}} ==Career== She started her long career in the consumer oil sector in 1993, working as an Export Manager for [[Agip|Agip Kenya Limited]] (AGKL), responsible for downstream distribution of fuels and oils from the depot in [[Mombasa]] to five countries in the [[African Great Lakes]] area, serving in that capacity until 1998. For one year, from 1998 until 1999, she served as the Customer Service Manager at AGKL. The next year, from 1999 until 2000, she served as the [[Liquefied petroleum gas|LPG]] Supervisor at AGKL. In 2000, she switched companies and moved over to [[Royal Dutch Shell| Shell]]/[[British Petroleum|BP]], as the LPG Manager, based in the coastal city of [[Malindi]], serving in that capacity until 2001. In 2001 she moved again, relocating to [[Chevron Corporation|Chevron]]/[[Caltex]] Kenya Limited, as a Sales Business Consultant, serving in that capacity for seven years. In 2008, Ms Mwangi was appointed the Head of Sales & Marketing division at the National Oil Corporation of Kenya (NOCK), serving in that capacity for the next five years. In July 2013, she was promoted to the position of General Manager, Downstream Operations at NOCK, serving in that capacity until July 2016, when she was appointed Acting Managing Director and Acting CEO.{{cite web|url=https://www.the-star.co.ke/news/2016/07/11/maryjane-mwangi-appointed-acting-national-oil-ceo_c1384345 |title=MaryJane Mwangi appointed acting National Oil CEO | accessdate=3 October 2017 |date=11 July 2016 |first=Patrick |last=Vidija |newspaper=[[The Star (Kenya)]] | location=Nirobi}} After performing in an active capacity for one year, MaryJane Mwangi was confirmed by the board of NOCK, as the substantive CEO and Managing Director, for a three-year term effective 1 August 2017, replacing Sumayya Hassan-Athmani, who had resigned in July 2016.{{cite web| url=http://www.businessdailyafrica.com/corporate/companies/National-Oil-MaryJane-Mwangi-CEO/4003102-4044866-12o7lgz/index.html | last=Herbling | title=Confirmation of National Oil boss could stoke conflict of interest debate |accessdate=3 November 2017 | date=4 August 2017 |location=Nairobi |first=David |newspaper=[[Business Daily Africa]] |publisher=[[Nation Media Group]]}} ==Other considerations== In July 2016, in her capacity as Acting CEO, she jointed the [[board of directors]] of NOCK, and has been a member since.{{cite web| url=https://www.bloomberg.com/research/stocks/private/person.asp?personId=256872740&privcapId=35929664&previousCapId=35929664&previousTitle=National%20Oil%20Corporation%20of%20Kenya%20Limited | title=Executive Profile of Mary Jane Mwangi, CEO & Director, National Oil Corporation of Kenya Limited | accessdate=3 November 2017 |date=3 November 2017 |last=Bloomberg | publisher=[[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg Research]]}} ==Family== MaryJane Mangi is married to Martin Mbogo, the Manager of Tullow Oil Kenya. ==See also== * [[Rebecca Miano]] * [[Josephine Wapakhabulo]] * [[Energy in Kenya]] {{Infobox person |name = Movsar Barayev |native_name = Мовсар Бухарович Бараев |native_name_lang = ru |image = |caption = Movsar Barayev in Moscow |birth_date = {{Birth-date|October 26, 1979}} |birth_place = [[Argun, Chechen Republic|Argun]], [[Chechen–Ingush Autonomous Soviet Socialist Republic|Chechen–Ingush ASSR]], [[Soviet Union]] |death_date = {{death-date and age|October 26, 2002|October 26, 1979}} |death_place = [[Moscow]], [[Russia]] |other_names = Movsar Suleimanov |known_for = [[Moscow theater hostage crisis|Moscow hostage crisis]] |occupation = |nationality = [[Chechen people|Chechen]] }}
'''Movsar Buharovich Barayev''' ({{lang-ru|Мовсар Бухарович Бараев}}; October 26, 1979 – October 26, 2002), earlier known as '''Suleimanov''', was a [[Chechen people|Chechen]] Islamist [[militia]] leader during the [[Second Chechen War]], who led [[Moscow theater hostage crisis|the seizure of a Moscow theater]] that led to the deaths of over 170 people.
==Life== Movsar Barayev, born 1979, was the nephew of the notorious Chechen [[warlord]] [[Arbi Barayev]] who allegedly worked under [[FSB (Russia)|FSB]] guidance.<ref name="Littell">[http://www.psan.occrg/document551.html The Security Organs of the Russian Federation. A Brief History 1991-2004]{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} by [[Jonathan Littell]], Psan Publishing House 2006.</ref> After his uncle's death in June 2001 until his own, Movsar was the leader of a Chechen terrorist militia known as the [[Special Purpose Islamic Regiment|Special Purpose Islamic Brigade]] (SPIR).<ref>[http://www.tol.cz/look/TOL/article.tpl?IdLanguage=1&IdPublication=10&NrIssue=498&NrSection=1&NrArticle=7567&ALStart=272 Reputed Warlord Barayev Killed] [[Transitions online]], 15 October 2002</ref> Barayev junior was said to be a sworn enemy of the Chechen leader and elected [[president]], [[Aslan Maskhadov]].<ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/chechnya/Story/0,2763,819079,00.html "Young, ruthless leader heads new generation of guerrillas"] ''[[The Guardian]]'', October 25, 2002</ref> He used the ''[[nom-de-guerre]]'' of '''"Yassir"'''.
He was incorrectly reported by the command of the [[Russia]]n forces in Chechnya to have been killed on August 21, 2001, and again on October 12, 2002, eleven days prior to the Moscow theater crisis (this report of Barayev's death came from Colonel Boris Podoprigora, deputy commander of Russia's Joint Group Forces).<ref>[http://www.gazeta.ru/2002/10/24/WhoisMovsarB.shtml Who is Movsar Barayev?] ''[[Gazeta.ru|Gazeta]]'', 24 October 2002</ref> It was also claimed that two months before the hostage-taking, the Russian [[GRU]] [[military intelligence]] had arrested Barayev and contained him ''"until his release had provided leads to the hostage taking at the [[Dubrovka Theater|Dubrovka]] theatre"''.<ref>[http://www.crimesofwar.org/chechnya-mag/chech-nivat.html Crimes of War > Chechnya Magazine: Brutality and Indifference] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070617092623/http://www.crimesofwar.org/chechnya-mag/chech-nivat.html |date=2007-06-17 }}</ref>
==Death== On October 23, 2002, Barayev and a mysterious man known as "Abu Bakar" led a group of some forty SPIR militants and their family members (who had dubbed themselves "the suicide squad from the 29th Division") to seize the theater in the Russian capital Moscow, demanding [[negotiations]] with Russian authorities for an end to [[Second Chechen War|the second war in Chechnya]], withdrawal of Russian forces and Chechen [[independence]],<ref>[http://www.ccc.nps.navy.mil/si/may03/russia.asp The Moscow Hostage Crisis: An Analysis of Chechen Terrorist Goals] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060809173640/http://www.ccc.nps.navy.mil/si/may03/russia.asp |date=2006-08-09 }}</ref> threatening to execute his hostages.
Movsar Barayev was killed on the third day of the crisis, when the Russian FSB special forces stormed the theater. He died on his 23rd birthday. Barayev's bloodied corpse was shown by the Russian TV lying on the ground of the theater amid broken glass with an intact bottle of [[Cognac (drink)|cognac]] near his hand. Later, the Russian authorities said his body was secretly buried in an undisclosed location.

[[Jean-Camille DeGrâce]] |successor7 = [[Wilfred Roussel]] |birth_date = {{birth date and age|1964|5|6}} |birth_place = [[Regional Municipality of Grand Tracadie–Sheila|Tracadie]], [[New Brunswick]] |death_date = |death_place = |party = [[Progressive Conservative Party of New Brunswick|Progressive Conservative]] }}
'''Paul Robichaud''' (born May 6, 1964 in [[Tracadie-Sheila, New Brunswick|Tracadie, New Brunswick]]) is a [[politician]] in the [[province (Canada)|province]] of [[New Brunswick]], [[Canada]].
He studied at the [[Shippagan, New Brunswick]] campus of the [[University of Moncton]]. A member of the [[Progressive Conservative Party of New Brunswick|Progressive Conservative Party]] since 1985, he first ran for office in the [[New Brunswick general election, 1995|1995]] but was defeated. He served from then until the next election as a [[Francophone]] organizer for the PC Party and ran again in [[New Brunswick general election, 1999|1999]] when he was successful becoming the member of the [[Legislative Assembly of New Brunswick]] for [[Lamèque-Shippagan-Miscou]]. He was re-elected in [[New Brunswick general election, 2003|2003]], [[New Brunswick general election, 2006|2006]] and [[New Brunswick general election, 2010|2010]].
He joined the cabinet first as [[Department of Fisheries and Aquaculture (New Brunswick)|Minister of Fisheries & Aquaculture]] and then became minister of the enlarged [[Department of Agriculture, Fisheries and Aquaculture (New Brunswick)|Department of Agriculture, Fisheries and Aquaculture]]. In a [[cabinet shuffle]] in 2001 he became [[Department of Tourism and Parks (New Brunswick)|Minister of Tourism & Parks]] a post he maintained until after the 2003 election when he took over the post of transportation.
He left the cabinet in 2006 as the [[New Brunswick Liberal Association|Liberals]] won that year's election and formed the government.

{{Infobox Officeholder |name =Prithvi Bahadur Pande |native_name = पृथ्वीबहादुर पाँडे |father = [[Bhim Bahadur Pande]] |office = Chairman of [[Nepal Investment Bank]] |office2 = Director of [[Himalayan Bank Limited]] |term2= non incumbent |website = }} '''Prithvi Bahadur Pande''' ({{lang-ne|पृथ्वीबहादुर पाँडे}}) is the chairman of [[Nepal Investment Bank Limited]] (NIBL).<ref name="nibl">{{cite web|url=https://www.nibl.com.np/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=88&Itemid=83|publisher=nibl.com.np|title=Board of Directors|accessdate=2017-06-11}}</ref> He is one of the successful banker who took over the French managed Indo-Suez Bank and successfully operated for more than 15 years.<ref name="spotlightnepal">{{cite web|url=http://www.spotlightnepal.com/News/Article/Investment-Bank-26th-AGM-Profit-|publisher=spotlightnepal.com|title=Investment Bank: Healthy Profit | NewSpotLight Nepal News Magazine|accessdate=2017-06-11}}</ref> He was an employee of [[Nepal Rastra Bank]] and had worked as director of [[Rastriya Banijya Bank]] and [[Himalayan Bank Limited]] before leading [[Nepal Investment Bank]] in 2001 through foreign investment.<ref name="bizmandu">{{cite web|url=http://www.bizmandu.com/content/-24688.html|publisher=bizmandu.com|title=बैंक १०/१२ मा झार्न राष्ट्र बैंकले ‘रिथिङ्क’ गर्नु पर्छ, पृथ्वीबहादुर पाँडेको अन्तर्वार्ता :: BIZMANDU|accessdate=2017-06-11}}</ref>
== Family == He is the son of diplomat-historian Sardar [[Bhim Bahadur Pande]]<ref name="setopati">{{cite web|url=http://m.setopati.net/news/6236/|publisher=m.setopati.net|title=Obituary: End of an era|accessdate=2017-06-11}}</ref> and eighth descendent of Nepalese [[Kaji (Nepal)|Kaji]] [[Kalu Pande]].<ref name="ekantipur">{{cite web|url=https://nepal.ekantipur.com/ampnews/2013-12-15/6239.html|publisher=nepal.ekantipur.com|title=ampnews/2013-12-15/6239|accessdate=2017-06-11}}</ref> He has married the eldest daughter of First Governor of Nepal [[Himalaya Shamsher Jang Bahadur Rana]].<ref name="setopati" />
